On March 5, 2025, a recognized student organization at Texas A&M University, the Texas A&M Queer Empowerment Council (the student group), filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Texas (No. 4:25‑cv‑00992) against members of the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents, the System Chancellor, and the University President, all in their official capacities. The case arises from a February 28, 2025 Board resolution directing cancellation of “Drag Show Events” in campus “Special Event Venues,” which led to cancellation of the student group’s annual, privately funded drag performance, “Draggieland,” scheduled for March 27, 2025 at the on-campus Rudder Theatre.

Parties and counsel. The plaintiff is a campus student organization that hosts expressive events supporting LGBTQ+ students. The defendants are the members of the Texas A&M System Board of Regents, the System Chancellor, and the Texas A&M President, sued in their official capacities. The plaintiff is represented by the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE), a nonprofit public‑interest First Amendment organization, with counsel admitted pro hac vice.

Legal foundation. The complaint asserts claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments based on viewpoint and content discrimination and prior restraint, seeks declaratory relief under 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–02, and brings a state-law claim to void the Board’s action under the Texas Open Meetings Act (Tex. Gov’t Code §§ 551.141, 551.142). The relief sought includes a temporary restraining order, preliminary and permanent injunctive relief, declaratory judgments, an order voiding actions taken at the February 28, 2025 meeting, and attorneys’ fees under 42 U.S.C. § 1988 and Tex. Gov’t Code § 551.142(b).

Factual basis. The University’s policies make campus facilities, including the Rudder Theatre Complex, available for student and sponsored events under content- and viewpoint‑neutral rules. Draggieland is a pageant‑style drag performance organized by the student group, historically successful and ticketed, with performers fully clothed and often discussing what drag means to them. The student group reserved Rudder Theatre on May 28, 2024 for March 27, 2025, received approval on October 23, 2024, and began ticket sales. On February 28, 2025, the Board adopted a resolution banning “Drag Show Events” from Special Event Venues, asserting such shows demean women, may contribute to a hostile environment under Title IX, and “promote gender ideology” in light of a January 20, 2025 federal executive order (Exec. Order No. 14168). The Chancellor directed campus presidents to cancel any such events, and Texas A&M officials notified the student group that Draggieland would not be permitted on campus; tickets already sold were refunded. The student group alleges the Board meeting was noticed less than 72 hours in advance in violation of the Texas Open Meetings Act.

Proceedings and rulings. The plaintiff moved for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction on March 5, 2025. The court set expedited briefing and held a hearing on March 18, 2025. On March 24, 2025, Senior U.S. District Judge Lee H. Rosenthal granted a preliminary injunction, enjoining enforcement of the Board’s resolution and ordering that Draggieland be permitted to proceed as scheduled on March 27, 2025, at 7:30 p.m. at Rudder Theatre. No bond was required, and the injunction remains effective until further order. Memorandum and Opinion (S.D. Tex. Mar. 24, 2025); Order of Injunction (S.D. Tex. Mar. 24, 2025).

In granting relief, the court found:
- Draggieland is protected speech and expressive conduct; the performance and performers’ discussions convey political, social, and cultural messages.
- The Rudder Theatre functions as a designated public forum; even if deemed a limited public forum, the Board’s ban is unconstitutional because it is viewpoint-based.
- The resolution is a prior restraint imposed before speech occurs and is unconstitutionally vague (undefined terms such as “lewd,” “vulgar,” and “sexualized”).
- The Board’s reliance on Title IX and a federal executive order does not supply a compelling, narrowly tailored basis to ban a once‑a‑year, ticketed, voluntary performance for adults; there was no evidence of severe or pervasive harassment tied to Draggieland.
- The plaintiff showed a likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable harm to First Amendment rights, and that the equities and public interest favor the injunction.

Important filings. Key filings include the complaint (Mar. 5, 2025), the motion for TRO/preliminary injunction (Mar. 5), expedited briefing and a March 18 hearing, and the preliminary injunction and memorandum and opinion (Mar. 24). An Answer was filed May 6, 2025. The state Open Meetings Act claim remains pending; the preliminary injunction addressed the federal First Amendment claims.

Appeal. The defendants noticed an appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit on March 28, 2025 (USCA No. 25‑20108) and moved to stay the injunction pending appeal. The record reflects briefing on the stay motion; the documents provided do not include a ruling on that motion or the appeal’s disposition.

Decree terms and duration. The preliminary injunction enjoins enforcement of the February 28, 2025 resolution and requires the University to permit the March 27, 2025 Draggieland performance at Rudder Theatre. No bond was required. The injunction remains in effect until further order of the court.

Context. The dispute centers on whether a public university may ban a student‑organized drag performance from a campus theater based on objections to its perceived ideology and alleged demeaning content. The court held that, under the First Amendment, the University may not impose a viewpoint‑based prior restraint on protected, adult‑audience expression in a campus forum opened for a wide range of performances and events.

Filing date: March 31, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

Parties: A nonprofit community development finance intermediary and GGRF grantee (the nonprofit grantee) sued the federal environmental agency (the agency), its Administrator and Acting Deputy Administrator in their official capacities (the agency head and acting deputy), and the bank serving as the federal financial agent for the grant accounts (the bank). The plaintiff is an organizational, individual plaintiff (not a class action).

Type of counsel: The nonprofit grantee is represented by private counsel (Venable LLP). The federal defendants are represented by government counsel. The bank is represented by private counsel.

Factual basis of the case: Congress, through the Inflation Reduction Act, created the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund (GGRF) and appropriated nearly $27 billion for three programs: National Clean Investment Fund (NCIF), Clean Communities Investment Accelerator (CCIA), and Solar for All. In April 2024, the agency awarded the nonprofit grantee $1.87 billion under CCIA; the grant period is April 1, 2024–June 30, 2030. Under a September 19, 2024 Financial Agency Agreement with Treasury, the bank serves as financial agent for all NCIF/CCIA funds. An Account Control Agreement among the agency, the bank, and the nonprofit grantee (effective November 6, 2024) governs the nonprofit grantee’s account and requires the bank to follow the grantee’s instructions absent a Notice of Exclusive Control from the agency; no such notice is alleged to have been issued.

Between November 2024 and mid‑February 2025, the nonprofit grantee pre‑qualified applicants and, after conferring weekly with the agency’s grant managers, selected 108 credit unions in 27 states and Puerto Rico for $651 million in initial subawards, notifying the agency on February 12 and 14. The complaint alleges that on February 12–13, 2025, after the first subrecipient notices, the agency head publicly announced an intent to claw back GGRF funds and return them to the Treasury, and the agency then froze GGRF funds; the bank allegedly declined to open subrecipient accounts or process drawdowns. On March 2–3, 2025, the agency referred GGRF to its Inspector General and issued a press release asserting concerns with program integrity, oversight, and potential waste, fraud, and abuse (without naming the nonprofit grantee). On March 4, 2025, the agency sent the nonprofit grantee a 35‑item information request. On March 11, 2025, the acting deputy issued a letter purporting to terminate all GGRF grant agreements, citing 2 C.F.R. §§ 200.339–.340 and “misalignment with the Agency’s priorities,” among other reasons; the letter did not offer a pre‑deprivation process or identify any specific noncompliance by the nonprofit grantee. The nonprofit grantee responded to the March 4 request on March 28 with an 18‑page letter and exhibits. The complaint further alleges that the bank continued to withhold funds and account openings notwithstanding the Account Control Agreement, and that funds were briefly moved out of the nonprofit grantee’s account on April 1, 2025 before being reinvested in money market funds (per counsel communications), prompting an emergency TRO request that was later withdrawn.

Cause of action and legal bases: Against the federal defendants, the nonprofit grantee asserts multiple Administrative Procedure Act (APA) claims (5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706): (1) contrary to the Inflation Reduction Act’s GGRF directives (42 U.S.C. § 7434); (2) contrary to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act’s rescission rules (2 U.S.C. § 683); (3) contrary to the Anti‑Deficiency Act (31 U.S.C. §§ 1341, 1512, 1517); (4) contrary to federal grant regulations (2 C.F.R. §§ 200.339–.342); and (5) arbitrary and capricious action. Constitutional claims allege separation‑of‑powers violations: Article I’s Legislative Vesting Clause, Spending Clause (Art. I, § 8, cl. 1), and Appropriations Clause (Art. I, § 9, cl. 7); Article II’s Take Care Clause (Art. II, § 3); and deprivation of due process under the Fifth Amendment. The complaint also pleads ultra vires agency action. Against the bank, the nonprofit grantee alleges breach of contract (Account Control Agreement), conversion, and replevin under New York law.

Remedies sought: Declaratory relief that the March 11, 2025 termination is void and that the freeze/termination violate the APA, federal statutes, and the Constitution; injunctive relief prohibiting the agency from giving effect to the termination, interfering with access to funds, or impeding the bank’s performance; and orders requiring the bank to honor the Account Control Agreement (including opening subrecipient accounts, processing draw requests, and not transferring funds except as directed by the nonprofit grantee or the Court). The nonprofit grantee also requested emergency restoration and protection of funds following the April 1 account balance issue.

Judge: U.S. District Judge Tanya S. Chutkan.

Filings and proceedings:
- March 31, 2025: Complaint filed.
- April 1, 2025: Motion for preliminary injunction filed, with exhibits including the grant agreements, Account Control Agreement, Financial Agency Agreement, and agency letters. An emergency TRO was also filed the same day after the grantee discovered a zero balance; later that day and evening, counsel for the agency and the bank attributed the movement to month‑end money market processes; the nonprofit grantee withdrew the TRO on April 2.
- April 7, 2025: Multiple pro hac vice motions for plaintiff’s counsel granted; appearances entered for federal defendants and the bank.
- April 10, 2025: On a joint status report, the Court stayed briefing on the preliminary injunction motion.
- April 15, 2025: The Court consolidated this case with Case No. 25‑cv‑698 under Rule 42(a)(2), designating 25‑cv‑698 as the lead case and directing future filings there.
- April 16, 2025: The Court denied the nonprofit grantee’s preliminary‑injunction motion as moot in light of a Preliminary Injunction Order entered in the lead case (25‑cv‑698), with a memorandum opinion to follow.

Consolidated/related cases: This case is consolidated with D.D.C. Case No. 25‑cv‑698, which involves other GGRF grantees and earlier resulted in a March 18, 2025 temporary restraining order. The Court’s April 16 order indicates that preliminary‑injunction relief in the lead case governs, mooting the separate preliminary‑injunction motion here.

Relief status and monitoring: No final merits ruling has issued in this docket. Preliminary‑injunction issues are controlled by the order in the consolidated lead case; no separate decree or settlement specific to this plaintiff is recorded on this docket. There is no court‑appointed monitor in this case.

Statutory and regulatory context referenced: Inflation Reduction Act, 42 U.S.C. § 7434 (GGRF); APA, 5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706; Impoundment Control Act, 2 U.S.C. § 683; Anti‑Deficiency Act, 31 U.S.C. §§ 1341, 1512, 1517; 12 U.S.C. § 265 (financial agents of the Government); Uniform Guidance, 2 C.F.R. §§ 200.339–.342; constitutional provisions cited above.

Current posture: The case is consolidated with 25‑cv‑698. The nonprofit grantee’s request for preliminary injunctive relief was denied as moot on April 16, 2025 because of the preliminary‑injunction order entered in the lead case. No trial or appeal is noted on this docket. The complaint seeks declaratory and permanent injunctive relief against the federal defendants and injunctive and contractual relief against the bank, along with restoration of access to the grant funds and implementation of the CCIA program as awarded.

On April 11, 2025, five individuals in F‑1 nonimmigrant status—two on post‑graduate Optional Practical Training (OPT) and three as current students at California universities—filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. They sued the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Acting Director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the Acting Field Office Director for ICE’s San Francisco office, and the President, all in their official capacities. The students are represented by private counsel from Van Der Hout LLP. The case is not a class action.

The students seek declaratory and injunctive relief under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706, and the Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–2202, and assert Fifth Amendment procedural due process claims. They challenge ICE’s termination of their Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS) records in early April 2025—which, according to entries visible to their schools, cited “Otherwise Failing to Maintain Status – Individual identified in criminal records check and/or has had their visa revoked.” Plaintiffs do not challenge any Department of State visa revocations per se; they allege that visa revocation does not terminate F‑1 status and that ICE lacks authority to terminate status or SEVIS records on the grounds cited. They seek a declaration that the SEVIS terminations were unlawful; vacatur and restoration of their SEVIS records and F‑1 statuses; and injunctions barring enforcement actions—including arrest, detention, transfer, or removal—arising from the SEVIS terminations or visa revocations, as well as costs and fees.

The complaint alleges each plaintiff remained in compliance with F‑1 requirements: one has a 2018 misdemeanor DUI conviction; one has a 2024 misdemeanor disturbing-the-peace conviction; one has no criminal history but previously received a 212(d)(3) waiver after an expedited removal; one had 2021 charges dismissed; and one had a 2024 arrest with no charges filed. Plaintiffs assert none of these circumstances constitutes a “crime of violence” or other failure to maintain status under 8 C.F.R. §§ 214.1(e)–(g) or 214.2(f), and that ICE may terminate status only in the limited situations listed at 8 C.F.R. § 214.1(d). Plaintiffs further allege their schools did not initiate the SEVIS terminations and that some plaintiffs received separate notices that their visas had been revoked.

Judge Noël Wise initially presided and granted Plaintiffs’ administrative motion to proceed under pseudonyms. On April 16, 2025, Plaintiffs filed a TRO motion. On April 17, 2025, Judge Wise granted the TRO, finding Plaintiffs had shown at least serious questions going to the merits of their APA claims and a likelihood of success, a likelihood of irreparable harm (including risk of arrest, transfer far from their communities, loss of studies or OPT, and significant anxiety), and that the balance of equities and public interest favored relief. For 14 days, the order: (1) enjoined Defendants from arresting and incarcerating Plaintiffs; (2) enjoined transferring Plaintiffs outside the district; and (3) enjoined imposing any legal effect that otherwise may be caused by the SEVIS terminations or potential visa revocations; it also required confidentiality protections and waived bond. The order set briefing and a hearing schedule.

On April 22, 2025, the case was related and reassigned to Judge Jeffrey S. White, who coordinated it with other Northern District cases presenting similar issues (including Doe v. Trump, No. 25‑cv‑03140‑JSW; Zhuoer Chen v. Noem, No. 25‑cv‑03292‑JSW; Emma Bai v. Lyons, No. 25‑cv‑03481‑JSW; and Sky Qui v. Lyons, No. 25‑cv‑03475‑JSW). In a Notice of Questions for the April 25 hearing, Judge White asked the government to address the legal consequences of SEVIS termination (referencing DHS’s own published guidance), who initiates terminations, available process, and whether any plaintiff had in fact “failed to maintain status.”

At the April 25, 2025 hearing, Judge White extended the TRO for an additional 14 days and set a preliminary injunction hearing in May, with supplemental briefing deadlines. On April 28, 2025, Defendants filed a “Statement Regarding Reactivation of Plaintiffs’ SEVIS Records,” reflecting that Plaintiffs’ SEVIS records had been reactivated. On April 30, 2025, Defendants filed a “Notice Regarding Policy,” and Plaintiffs filed a supplemental PI brief the same day. Following further briefing and a hearing held on May 14, 2025, Judge White granted preliminary injunctions on May 22, 2025, in this and several related cases. (The record provided does not include the full text of the PI order; the court set a joint case management conference and later continued it.)

Judge Wise’s TRO and Judge White’s subsequent orders relied on APA principles that termination of SEVIS status is reviewable final agency action and, on the limited record, likely exceeded DHS/ICE authority and was arbitrary and capricious under 5 U.S.C. § 706(2). The court also found irreparable harm from loss of studies or employment and risk of detention or removal, and emphasized the public interest in adherence to due process and administrative law.

Defendants noticed an appeal to the Ninth Circuit on July 21, 2025 (USCA No. 25‑4523) from the preliminary injunction order, and later moved in the district court to stay the injunction pending appeal (motion filed August 8, 2025; hearing set for September 12, 2025). As of the latest entries provided, no trial has occurred, no settlement has been reported, and there is no court‑appointed monitor.

Factual context: Plaintiffs allege that, beginning around April 4, 2025, DHS/ICE terminated hundreds of F‑1 students’ SEVIS records nationwide using a status‑violation code tied to “criminal records check and/or visa revoked,” without school initiation, legal authority, or prior notice, and that some students were detained and transferred far from their schools and communities. Plaintiffs contend visa revocation after admission does not itself terminate F‑1 status or justify SEVIS termination, and that ICE must pursue any removability allegations through immigration court, not by unilateral SEVIS terminations. The court’s early orders preserved the status quo, barred arrests and transfers, and ultimately granted preliminary injunctive relief after Defendants reported reactivation of Plaintiffs’ SEVIS records. Judge Jeffrey S. White presides; Judge Noël Wise issued the initial TRO before reassignment.

Filing date and forum. The case was filed on April 29, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia as Civil Action No. 25-1305 (RDM).

Parties and posture. The Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB), its Board of Directors, and three sitting directors (suing in their official capacities) sued the President, the White House Presidential Personnel Office and its leadership, and the Office of Management and Budget and its director, all in their official capacities. This is not a class action. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel (Saul Ewing LLP). Defendants appeared through government counsel.

Factual basis. CPB is a private, nonprofit corporation created by Congress in the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967 (PBA), with statutory safeguards against federal direction, supervision, or control. On April 28, 2025, the Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel emailed three of the five sitting CPB directors stating, “On behalf of President Donald J. Trump, I am writing to inform you that your position on the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is terminated effective immediately.” The email cited no authority. Plaintiffs allege the Executive Branch lacks power to remove CPB directors and sought court intervention, noting broader concerns about potential executive interference (including a DOGE staffer’s follow-up email proposing to “discuss getting a DOGE team assigned” to CPB and citing contemporaneous events at the U.S. Institute of Peace).

Claims and legal bases. Plaintiffs assert:
- Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–2202 (to declare the removal email legally ineffective).
- Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A), (C) (agency action not in accordance with law and in excess of statutory authority).
- Constitutional claims: separation of powers; violations of the Presentment Clause, the Appropriations Clause, and the Take Care Clause.
- Statutory foundation: Public Broadcasting Act, principally 47 U.S.C. §§ 396 and 398, which (1) establishes CPB as a private nonprofit, not a federal agency, (2) provides that directors are not officers or employees of the United States, and (3) forbids federal direction, supervision, or control over CPB.

Remedies sought. Plaintiffs seek: (1) a declaratory judgment that the April 28, 2025 removal email is of no legal effect; and (2) injunctive relief barring any steps to give effect to the email or otherwise to interfere with CPB’s governance and operations. They also seek fees and costs.

Judge. U.S. District Judge Randolph D. Moss presides.

Proceedings and rulings.
- April 29, 2025: Plaintiffs filed the complaint and a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO). The court held an emergency conference, set briefing, and scheduled a hearing.
- May 14, 2025: At the hearing, the parties agreed to treat the TRO as a motion for a preliminary injunction.
- June 8, 2025: The court denied preliminary injunctive relief without prejudice. Memorandum Opinion and Order, ECF No. 32.
  • Likelihood of success: On the current record, Plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success. The court emphasized the PBA’s incorporation of D.C. nonprofit law “to the extent consistent” with the PBA, and noted D.C. Code § 29-406.08(e) permits the appointing person to remove an appointed director unless the articles or bylaws provide otherwise. At the time of the April 28 email, CPB’s bylaws did not restrict removal; CPB amended its bylaws on May 15, 2025 to require a two‑thirds vote of the other directors to confirm any removal. The court found Plaintiffs’ arguments that PBA § 396(c)(7) (forfeiture for nonattendance) is the exclusive removal mechanism unconvincing, and concluded the PBA’s noninterference provisions did not foreclose application of the D.C. removal rule. The court also noted that federal appointment constraints (Senate advice and consent) and CPB’s bylaw “designated body” mechanism under D.C. Code § 29-406.12 mitigate risks of executive control.
  • Irreparable harm: Plaintiffs did not show likely irreparable injury. The record did not show imminent takeover or invasion of CPB premises; CPB could continue to operate (the quorum is a majority of directors “in office” and “any vacancy … shall not affect [the Board’s] power,” 47 U.S.C. § 396(c)(6)); and CPB’s bylaws permit a “designated body” to act if the Board falls below the statutory minimum.
  • Scope: The court denied the preliminary injunction without prejudice to renewal if defendants or those acting with them take steps to interfere with CPB’s independence.
- June 29, 2025: The court granted a joint motion to expedite summary-judgment briefing (Plaintiffs’ motion due July 25; Defendants’ opposition and cross-motion due Aug. 29; Plaintiffs’ reply/opposition due Sept. 19; Defendants’ reply due Oct. 10).
- July 24 and Aug. 1, 2025: Two individual director-plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed their claims, leaving CPB, its Board, and one director-plaintiff. Plaintiffs filed their summary-judgment motion on July 25, 2025.

Reported opinions. Memorandum Opinion and Order denying preliminary injunction (June 8, 2025), ECF No. 32.

Appeals, trials, settlements, and decrees. No appeals, trials, consent decrees, or settlements are reflected in the record provided. No monitors were appointed.

Context and statutory framework. Congress created CPB as a private nonprofit under the PBA, specifying it is not a federal agency and that its directors are not federal officers or employees. The Act forbids federal direction, supervision, or control over CPB and its grantees and protects editorial independence. The President appoints CPB directors with Senate advice and consent; the PBA is silent on removal except for automatic forfeiture for insufficient attendance. The court’s preliminary ruling applied the D.C. Nonprofit Corporation Act’s default rule allowing the appointing authority to remove appointed directors unless restricted by the organization’s governing documents, and noted CPB later amended its bylaws to require a supermajority board confirmation for any removal. The court also highlighted D.C. law and CPB bylaws provisions allowing a temporary “designated body” to act if the Board falls below the statutory minimum, thereby enabling continued operations.

Filing date and court. The case was filed on April 7, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia, Charleston Division. It is assigned to Judge Irene C. Berger.

Parties and posture. A coal miner employed in West Virginia filed suit individually and on behalf of similarly situated coal miners (a putative class) against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Secretary of HHS in his official capacity. The plaintiffs are represented by a mix of private and nonprofit public‑interest counsel. The defendants are represented by government counsel.

Factual background. Black lung (coal workers’ pneumoconiosis) is a progressive, incurable disease caused by mine dust exposure; early detection and limiting further dust exposure can slow or halt progression. Federal law requires HHS to administer the Coal Workers’ Health Surveillance Program (CWHSP) and to implement the “Part 90” job‑transfer option: when HHS determines a miner has evidence of pneumoconiosis, the miner may transfer to lower‑dust work without loss of pay. See 30 U.S.C. § 843; 42 C.F.R. Part 37; 30 C.F.R. Part 90. Within HHS, NIOSH’s Respiratory Health Division (RHD) in Morgantown, West Virginia, performs these functions, including free screenings, evaluation of radiographs and spirometry, issuing Part 90 letters, certifying B‑Readers, operating a mobile clinic, and approving mine screening plans.

The named miner was diagnosed with black lung by a local clinic in November 2024 and by the West Virginia Occupational Pneumoconiosis Board in January 2025 (early‑stage disease). He submitted an application and imaging to NIOSH in November 2024; he testified he received no response despite calls. Defendants produced a December 10, 2024 letter stating an October 2023 CT scan did not show findings consistent with black lung. The miner testified he would have submitted additional evidence and sought renewed screening if the program were operating.

On or about April 1, 2025, HHS issued Reduction in Force (RIF) notices to most RHD employees, placed them on administrative leave, and paused the CWHSP. Approved facilities were told NIOSH could not accept new radiographs, spirometry, or forms and would suspend electronic submission accounts. RHD staff testified they received RIF notices (June/July effective dates), were on leave, had been told their duties were unnecessary or duplicative, and had not been asked to transition work or train replacements. HHS issued press releases describing a broader HHS restructuring but did not identify any plan to continue CWHSP or Part 90 functions elsewhere. Evidence showed CWHSP processed nearly 5,000 radiographs in FY 2024 and that its activities (including B‑Reader certification and the mobile unit) are specialized and not duplicated elsewhere in government. Witnesses emphasized that miners cannot access Part 90 rights without a NIOSH determination and that continued dust exposure accelerates disease.

Legal foundation and claims. The complaint asserts:
- Administrative Procedure Act (APA) claims to compel unlawfully withheld/unreasonably delayed agency action and to set aside arbitrary and capricious action not in accordance with law. 5 U.S.C. §§ 702, 706.
- A declaratory judgment claim. 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–2202.
- A Fifth Amendment procedural due process claim, alleging deprivation of statutory health‑screening and transfer benefits without notice or hearing.
The statutory framework includes 30 U.S.C. § 843 (mandatory miner examinations and transfer rights); 30 U.S.C. § 811(a)(7), (a)(9) (examination authority; anti‑backsliding); 29 U.S.C. § 671 (establishing NIOSH and its Office of Mine Safety and Health); implementing regulations at 42 C.F.R. Part 37 and 30 C.F.R. Part 90; and appropriation statutes funding NIOSH/CWHSP. Plaintiffs also referenced the Impoundment Control Act, 2 U.S.C. §§ 682–88. The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief restoring the RHD/CWHSP and compelling HHS to comply with § 843 and related duties, class certification under Rule 23(b)(2), and fees and costs.

Key motions and proceedings.
- April 21, 2025: The miner filed an amended complaint and moved for a preliminary injunction. The court set a May 7, 2025 evidentiary hearing.
- May 1, 2025: Defendants moved to dismiss and to dismiss the jury demand; they also moved to seal exhibits and to quash a subpoena to a NIOSH physician (the subpoena was quashed).
- May 7, 2025: The court held the preliminary‑injunction hearing, receiving testimony from miners, RHD epidemiologists, and a former RHD/CWHSP coordinator.
- May 13, 2025: The court granted the preliminary injunction. Mem. Op. & Order, ECF No. 36 (S.D.W. Va. May 13, 2025).

Court’s preliminary‑injunction ruling. The court found the miner likely to succeed on the merits, would suffer irreparable harm absent relief, and that the balance of equities and public interest favored an injunction.
- Standing and sovereign immunity. The miner had standing as an active miner with a black lung diagnosis who could not access CWHSP screenings or obtain a NIOSH Part 90 determination; the APA’s waiver of sovereign immunity applied. The closure was final agency action with legal consequences for miners. The court rejected defendants’ characterization of the case as a personnel dispute governed exclusively by the Civil Service Reform Act, holding the claims challenge the elimination of statutory services to program beneficiaries.
- Likelihood of success. The court found the CWHSP/RHD effectively shut down and that HHS provided no plan or reasoned basis to continue the mandated functions; miners cannot access Part 90 protections without NIOSH. The shutdown was arbitrary and capricious and contrary to law because it prevented HHS from fulfilling obligations under the Mine Act and implementing regulations. Press releases about restructuring did not undermine finality or justify pausing statutorily mandated services.
- Irreparable harm and public interest. Ongoing dust exposure causes irreversible progression of disease; cancelling CWHSP/Part 90 would cost lives. The public interest favored enforcing statutory protections; “there is no public interest in the perpetuation of unlawful agency action.”
- Relief ordered. The court enjoined and rescinded the RIFs in the NIOSH Respiratory Health Division to facilitate full restoration of the RHD, including health surveillance through CWHSP and the Part 90 program. It ordered that, even in any reorganization, there be no pause, stoppage, or gap in services mandated by Congress. The Secretary was required to file written certification of compliance within 20 days. Bond was set at zero. Defendants filed a certification on June 2, 2025.

Subsequent case status. A scheduling order issued on June 17, 2025 set discovery and trial dates, including a trial date of May 4, 2026. On August 14, 2025, the court granted leave for the plaintiff to file a second amended complaint and terminated as moot the defendants’ then‑pending motion to dismiss and motion to dismiss the jury demand. Class certification has not been adjudicated. No appeals are noted in the record provided.

Remedies sought and obtained. Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief compelling HHS to operate the CWHSP and Part 90 program consistent with 30 U.S.C. § 843 and the regulations, restoration of RHD staffing sufficient to perform those duties, and class‑wide relief under Rule 23(b)(2). The court entered preliminary injunctive relief requiring full restoration of RHD/CWHSP operations and prohibiting any gap in protections, with compliance certification required; the injunction remains in effect pending further order. No monetary damages are sought.

On May 17, 2025, a detained Venezuelan asylum applicant filed a habeas petition under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and a class action complaint in the Central District of California against federal executive officials and agencies (the President, the Attorney General, the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Departments of Homeland Security, Defense, and State, ICE and its officials, and a private facility warden). The detainee is held at the Desert View Annex associated with ICE’s Adelanto Processing Center. He alleges that, after appearing for a scheduled ICE check‑in, he was arrested without prior notice and that, because he is a Venezuelan with tattoos, officials suspected links to Tren de Aragua. He contends he is potentially subject to Proclamation No. 10903 (Mar. 14, 2025), which invoked the Alien Enemies Act (AEA), 50 U.S.C. §§ 21 et seq., to authorize the immediate apprehension and removal of certain Venezuelan nationals. He seeks classwide declaratory and injunctive relief and a writ of habeas corpus, asserting violations of the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause (among other constitutional and statutory claims), including a right to advance notice and an opportunity to challenge any AEA removal. Petitioner is represented by private counsel.

On May 19, 2025, Judge John W. Filed May 22, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, this case challenges attempts by the President to remove the head of the U.S. Copyright Office and to install an acting Librarian of Congress. The plaintiff is the Register of Copyrights and Director of the U.S. Copyright Office, suing individually. The defendants are: the person claiming to be acting Librarian of Congress (also serving as Deputy Attorney General), the person claiming to be acting Register of Copyrights (a Justice Department official), the Executive Office of the President, the Director and Deputy Director of the White House Presidential Personnel Office, and the President in his official capacity. The plaintiff is represented by Democracy Forward Foundation (public-interest counsel) and Munger, Tolles & Olson LLP (private counsel). This is not a class action.

The complaint alleges that on May 8, 2025, the President removed the sitting Librarian of Congress. Two days later, a White House official emailed the Register that her position was terminated “effective immediately,” and the President amplified a media report of her firing. The next day, the Deputy Attorney General—whom the President had directed to perform the duties of the Librarian—designated a Justice Department official as acting Register and another as acting Deputy Librarian; those officials attempted to assume their posts at the Library of Congress but left after Library staff contacted the U.S. Capitol Police. The Register maintains she remains in office because only the Librarian of Congress may appoint and remove the Register, and, under Library rules, the Principal Deputy Librarian became the acting Librarian upon the Librarian’s removal.

Legal foundation. The plaintiff brings two counts seeking declaratory and injunctive relief: (1) an ultra vires claim that the President’s designation of an acting Librarian of Congress is unauthorized by the Constitution or statute, because the Federal Vacancies Reform Act applies only to “Executive agency” positions and not to the Library of Congress, and (2) a constitutional claim that removing the Register violated the Appointments Clause and separation of powers because Congress vested appointment—and thus removal—of the Register in the Librarian of Congress under 17 U.S.C. § 701(a). She seeks declarations that the Vacancies Reform Act does not authorize an acting Librarian of Congress; that she remains the Register; that the Deputy Attorney General was not lawfully appointed as acting Librarian; and that the Principal Deputy Librarian remains the acting Librarian. She also seeks to enjoin the claimed acting Librarian and claimed acting Register from exercising those offices and to bar interference with her access to the Copyright Office absent action by a lawfully appointed Librarian. Jurisdiction is invoked under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 1361, 1651, 2201, and 2202.

Judge. U.S. District Judge Timothy J. Kelly is presiding.

Filings and proceedings. On May 22, 2025, the plaintiff moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO). After briefing and a May 28 hearing, the Court denied the TRO, finding she had not shown irreparable harm. The Court then set an expedited briefing schedule for a preliminary injunction. The plaintiff filed her motion on June 10; defendants opposed on June 24; the plaintiff replied on July 1. Following a July 23 hearing, the Court denied the preliminary injunction on July 30, 2025, again concluding the plaintiff failed to establish irreparable harm as required by Winter v. NRDC. The Court held that a temporary loss of a “statutory right to function” in office and the temporary inability to discharge statutory duties do not, without more, constitute the “genuinely extraordinary” irreparable injury required in government-personnel cases under Sampson v. Murray. The Court also held the plaintiff could not rely on alleged harms to the Library of Congress or the Copyright Office to establish her own irreparable harm, and noted there was no showing the Copyright Office would be shuttered or unable to operate during the litigation. See Mem. Op., ECF No. 40 (D.D.C. July 30, 2025). On July 31, 2025, the plaintiff noticed an appeal to the D.C. Circuit (No. 25-5285). She then sought an injunction pending appeal; the Court denied that motion on August 20, 2025, for the same irreparable-harm reasons. See Mem., ECF No. 48 (D.D.C. Aug. 20, 2025). The Court has set a merits schedule for cross-motions for summary judgment (opening September 8, 2025; hearing November 4, 2025). No trial has been held.

On April 14, 2022, the United States filed a civil action in the District of South Carolina against the state juvenile justice department over conditions at its long‑term juvenile commitment facility, the Broad River Road Complex in Columbia. The United States alleged a pattern or practice of conduct that deprives confined youth of federal rights, in violation of 34 U.S.C. § 12601, grounded in the Fourteenth Amendment’s Due Process Clause. The United States sought declaratory and injunctive relief.

The suit followed a multi‑year federal investigation. In a February 5, 2020 findings report, the Department of Justice concluded there was reasonable cause to believe BRRC failed to keep youth reasonably safe from youth‑on‑youth violence and used prolonged, punitive isolation, in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment. Contributing factors included inadequate staffing and supervision, insufficient training and behavior management tools, serious safety blind spots and weak surveillance coverage, and physical plant design that impeded supervision. DOJ documented frequent fights and assaults with injuries; extensive use of isolation for non‑dangerous behaviors (e.g., profanity, “disrespect,” being “out of place”); lengthy isolation in small, dark 8-by‑8 cells for 23 hours a day without meaningful schooling or programs; and deterioration in mental health and self‑harm while in isolation. DOJ also noted that its ADA inquiry into secure evaluation centers did not reveal a violation. A prior federal case in the 1990s had resulted in injunctive relief to remedy unconstitutional juvenile conditions statewide, but concerns reemerged at BRRC in recent years.

In a second report dated April 14, 2022, DOJ found a pattern of unreasonable force by staff. Examples included choking, punching, kicking, twisting arms, dragging youth in restraints, applying body weight to prone youth, and restraining youth for verbal non‑compliance. Some incidents occurred off camera and went unreported by staff. DOJ found investigations were inadequately initiated, delayed, hampered by short video‑retention and blind spots, and too often declined in the absence of a formal complaint, leading to undercounting of excessive‑force events.

Simultaneous with filing the complaint, the parties executed a comprehensive Settlement Agreement dated April 13, 2022. The agreement requires the juvenile justice department to:
- Protection from harm: conduct an independent staffing study within nine months and implement recommended staffing pattern changes within 18 months of receiving the study; expand surveillance to cover blind spots on a DOJ‑approved timeline and retain video long enough for investigations and oversight; provide structured rehabilitative programming after school and on weekends; implement a positive behavior management system with incentives and de‑escalation strategies; and revise and implement a use‑of‑force policy that limits force and restraints to imminent, serious danger, requires exhaustion of lesser interventions, mandates prompt medical evaluation, complete reporting, and swift supervisory review and corrective action.
- Investigations: adopt policies within nine months (implemented within 18 months) mandating initial reviews of all force, youth‑on‑youth harm, and isolation incidents; full, timely investigations (generally within ten business days) of specified incidents by trained, uninvolved investigators; early video preservation; continuation of investigations even if a youth declines to pursue charges; and appropriate corrective discipline.
- Isolation: revise policies within nine months (implemented within 18 months) to bar isolation for punishment, retaliation, protective custody, suicide intervention, or as temporary housing; allow isolation only when the youth poses a serious and immediate danger and lesser measures have failed; require leadership approval to extend isolation beyond four hours, daily in‑person mental‑health and leadership reviews for any extension, and multidisciplinary team reviews within 48 hours and at least every three days thereafter; stop using the Laurel Building for isolation per a DOJ‑approved plan; ensure humane conditions and timely, meaningful education in isolation; screen and house vulnerable youth appropriately with equal access to services; ensure suicidal youth are not placed in isolation; and coordinate with the state mental health department to expedite transfers of youth with serious mental illness or suicidal youth to appropriate treatment placements.
- Training and quality assurance: develop competency‑based training on behavior management, de‑escalation, and the revised use‑of‑force and investigation policies; retrain and, if necessary, discipline staff for failures; and build a quality‑assurance system within 24 months to track key safety and isolation metrics monthly, review samples of incidents and investigations, and operate a Quality Improvement Committee to identify trends and corrective actions.

Implementation and monitoring provisions include appointment (within 60 days) of a jointly selected Subject Matter Expert to provide technical assistance and assess compliance, with semiannual public compliance reports and a defined budget; designation of a Director of Settlement Compliance within the agency (Wendy Leach); DOJ‑approved annual Implementation Plans; and monthly and quarterly/sem iannual meetings between the parties. The parties stipulated the relief complies with the Prison Litigation Reform Act.

Proceedings and court rulings: The case was assigned to Judge Mary Geiger Lewis. On April 20, 2022, the court granted the parties’ joint motion and dismissed the action without prejudice, retaining jurisdiction to reinstate the case upon a DOJ motion alleging a material breach of the Agreement. There were no trials or appeals and no reported opinions.

Settlement duration and enforcement: The agency must implement all provisions within four years. The Agreement may terminate after five years if the parties agree the agency has attained substantial compliance with all provisions and maintained it for one year, or upon a court finding of durable constitutional compliance. The United States may seek to restore the case to the active docket to address material breaches, and the court retains jurisdiction to resolve disputes. Counsel: The United States was represented by the Department of Justice Civil Rights Division and the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the District of South Carolina; the state juvenile justice department was represented by private counsel. The plaintiffs are not a class; the case was brought by the United States pursuant to statute.

Factual basis: DOJ documented frequent youth‑on‑youth assaults and injuries, staff use of excessive and disproportionate force, inadequate staffing and training, blind spots and poor video retention impeding supervision and investigations, punitive and prolonged isolation in harsh conditions with minimal services, and worsening mental health and self‑harm among youth subjected to isolation. The Agreement addresses these conditions with mandated reforms, training, monitoring, and timelines.

The defense was initially represented by the Federal Public Defender and later by private counsel; the government is represented by the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

The grand jury charged one count of conspiracy to unlawfully transport noncitizens for financial gain, in violation of 8 U.S.C. § 1324(a)(1)(A)(v) and (B)(i), and one count of unlawful transportation of noncitizens for financial gain, in violation of 8 U.S.C. § 1324(a)(1)(A)(ii) and (B)(i). Arraignment and a detention hearing were held June 13, 2025, with testimony from a Homeland Security Investigations agent and exhibits including body camera footage from the November 2022 stop, a passenger roster, and protective order records. On June 22, 2025, the Magistrate Judge denied the motion for detention, finding the government had not established grounds to hold a detention hearing under § 3142(f)—specifically, that the case (i) did not “involve a minor victim” within § 3142(f)(1)(E) based on the evidentiary record presented, (ii) did not present a “serious risk” of flight within § 3142(f)(2)(A), and (iii) did not present a “serious risk” of obstruction or intimidation within § 3142(f)(2)(B). The Magistrate Judge further found that, even if a hearing were authorized, conditions could reasonably assure appearance and community safety under § 3142(g). The Magistrate Judge set a hearing to review release conditions.

The District Judge held the government had shown it was entitled to a detention hearing under § 3142(f)(1)(E) because, applying the Second Circuit’s approach to the term “involves,” the charged conduct more likely than not involved minor victims, but nonetheless concluded that the government had not shown by clear and convincing evidence that no combination of conditions could reasonably assure community safety or, by a preponderance, the defendant’s appearance. On July 1, 2025, three city governments (Columbus, Baltimore, and Chicago), a nationwide association of physicians and trainees, and a national small‑business network filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland challenging the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) over a final regulation titled “Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; Marketplace Integrity and Affordability,” 90 Fed. Reg. 27,074 (June 25, 2025). The federal health department and its leadership (HHS, CMS, the HHS Secretary, and CMS Administrator) promulgated the rule with an August 25, 2025 effective date. Plaintiffs are represented by the Democracy Forward Foundation (public‑interest nonprofit counsel).

The suit proceeds under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 701 et seq., alleging several provisions of the rule are contrary to law and arbitrary and capricious. Plaintiffs contend the rule conflicts with and undermines the Affordable Care Act (ACA), including the guaranteed‑issue and renewability requirements (42 U.S.C. §§ 300gg‑1, 300gg‑2), the premium‑tax‑credit scheme (26 U.S.C. § 36B; 42 U.S.C. §§ 18081, 18082), and ACA § 1554’s bar on unreasonable barriers to care (42 U.S.C. § 18114). They seek declaratory relief, vacatur, a stay of the effective date under APA § 705, preliminary and permanent injunctions, and fees.

Factual context: Plaintiffs assert the rule will raise net premiums and out‑of‑pocket limits, erode plan value, add documentation hurdles, and narrow eligibility, causing widespread loss of ACA marketplace coverage (CMS and CBO estimates noted up to 1.8 million in 2026) and shifting uncompensated care costs to safety‑net providers and municipalities. Challenged elements include: a $5 monthly charge for auto‑reenrolled zero‑premium enrollees pending eligibility reconfirmation; a new premium‑nonpayment policy allowing issuers to refuse new coverage until past‑due premiums are paid; restoration of a one‑year “failure‑to‑reconcile” tax rule cutting off APTCs; expansion of pre‑enrollment verification for special enrollment periods (SEPs); revised data‑matching/income‑verification rules (including removal of a 60‑day extension and rejection of self‑attestation when no IRS data); broader “de minimis” ranges for actuarial value; and a permanent change to the premium‑adjustment‑percentage methodology that incorporates individual‑market data. Plaintiffs later narrowed their immediate request and did not seek a stay of the low‑income SEP elimination in light of subsequent legislation.

Procedural history and rulings: Plaintiffs moved on July 2, 2025 for a § 705 stay or, alternatively, a preliminary injunction. After briefing and an August 14, 2025 hearing, Judge Brendan A. Hurson issued a memorandum opinion on August 22, 2025, granting in part and denying in part a stay under § 705 and finding standing for the small‑business association (through a member facing premium‑driven business closure) and for the city governments (predictable uncompensated‑care costs). The court found irreparable harm (no monetary remedy under the APA; imminent market effects before open enrollment) and that the balance of equities and public interest favored relief.

Likelihood of success and stayed provisions: The court concluded Plaintiffs showed a strong likelihood of success on seven provisions. It stayed their effective dates pending final judgment:
- $5 “junk fee” on auto‑reenrolled zero‑premium enrollees (contrary to law; HHS lacks authority to alter the statutory APTC formula).
- Revocation of guaranteed issue for applicants with past‑due premiums (contrary to the ACA’s guaranteed‑issue mandate, which does not include this exception).
- One‑year “failure‑to‑reconcile” (FTR) bar on APTCs (contrary to law; cannot add a reconciliation condition to statutory credit eligibility; the agency’s reopening of the issue allowed review).
- Expansion of pre‑enrollment eligibility verification to at least 75% of SEP enrollments on the federal platform (arbitrary and capricious; mismatch between asserted fraud concerns and evidence; undue enrollment barriers).
- Mandatory income verification when an attested income (100–400% FPL) exceeds IRS data showing below 100% FPL (arbitrary and capricious; reliance on flawed studies; inadequate response to comments).
- Expansion of “de minimis” actuarial value ranges (arbitrary and capricious; conclusory reasoning and consideration of improper factors without evidentiary support).
- Elimination of self‑attestation when IRS tax data are unavailable (arbitrary and capricious; unsupported assumptions, insufficient explanation of burdens versus program‑integrity gains).

Provisions not stayed: The court declined to stay two items, finding Plaintiffs had not shown a likelihood of success: (1) the change to the premium‑adjustment‑percentage methodology (reasoned policy shift aligned with statute despite cost impacts), and (2) removal of the automatic 60‑day extension to resolve income inconsistencies (Plaintiffs unlikely to show the agency exceeded its authority).

Relief and scope: By order dated August 25, 2025, the court clarified and enumerated the stayed provisions. It issued a § 705 stay of their effective dates “pending a final ruling on the merits,” declined to require a bond, and explained the APA permits postponing an agency rule’s effective date; the stay was not limited to the named Plaintiffs. No trial has occurred and no appeal is noted. The principal reported decision is the court’s Memorandum Opinion (Aug. 22, 2025) (ECF 35). The court referenced, among other authorities, City of Columbus v. Cochran, 523 F. Supp. 3d 731 (D. Md. 2021), which vacated a similar income‑verification policy, and Loper Bright, which guides courts’ independent review of agency statutory interpretations.

Related matters: The case is not consolidated with others. Plaintiffs abandoned their request to stay the rule’s elimination of a monthly SEP for certain low‑income consumers after intervening legislation. The stay of seven provisions remains in effect pending final judgment.

On April 10, 2025, sixteen states, the District of Columbia, and the Governor of Pennsylvania (in his official capacity) sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education in the Southern District of New York (Judge Edgardo Ramos). The states—represented by their Attorneys General (public counsel)—challenge, under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Department’s sudden rescission of previously granted extensions of time to liquidate Education Stabilization Fund grants made under COVID‑19 relief laws, including the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (ARP) and the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act of 2020 (CRRSA). The Department is represented by the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

Background. During the pandemic, Congress appropriated substantial K‑12 funds through the Education Stabilization Fund, including ESSER (elementary/secondary), HCY (homeless children and youth), and EANS (nonpublic schools). Statutes required obligations by specified dates (extended one year by GEPA’s “Tydings” provision). Regulations allowed liquidation within 120 days after the period of performance, and authorized the Department to extend liquidation “when justified.” 2 C.F.R. § 200.344(c). In 2023–2025, after inviting applications, the Department approved states’ requests for late liquidation, commonly through March 28, 2026 (ARP programs) and to March 31, 2025 (some CRRSA awards). States and their school districts obligated funds by the statutory deadlines and relied on the extensions to continue projects such as tutoring, mental‑health services, and HVAC and facility upgrades.

Agency action. On March 28, 2025, at 5:03 p.m. ET, the Department emailed a letter from the Secretary rescinding those extensions effective 5:00 p.m. that same day and declaring the liquidation periods expired. The letter asserted that extending COVID‑related grants years after the pandemic’s end was inconsistent with Department priorities and that any reliance interests were minimal and unreasonable. On April 3, 2025, and again on May 11, 2025, the Department issued “Dear Colleague” letters announcing a new, project‑specific extension process and stating that any previously extended liquidation periods would terminate on May 25, 2025, while providing a 14‑day wind‑down. The May 11 letter characterized the earlier approvals as unprecedented and inadequately justified and stated that no valid reliance interests existed.

Claims and relief. The states assert APA violations, alleging the rescission was arbitrary and capricious and contrary to law: it reversed prior approvals without a reasoned explanation, failed to consider substantial reliance interests, misapplied the extension criteria, and treated grant availability as tied to the public health emergency despite statute allowing post‑emergency use. They seek declaratory relief, vacatur of the rescission, reinstatement of the extensions through March 28, 2026, and injunctive relief. No damages are sought.

Proceedings and rulings. On April 11, 2025, the states moved for a preliminary injunction. After argument, on May 6, 2025, Judge Ramos preliminarily enjoined enforcement of the March 28 rescission and required at least 14 days’ advance notice before modifying previously approved liquidation periods; he also directed the Department to notify personnel and file a status report. The Department then issued the May 11 letter. The states sought emergency relief; on May 20, 2025, the court issued a TRO enjoining the May 11 letter and set a June 3 hearing. On June 3, 2025, the court entered a second preliminary injunction (bond: $1,000): (1) enjoining enforcement of the March 28 and May 11 letters; (2) prohibiting any attempt to modify the previously approved liquidation periods without at least 30 days’ notice; and (3) directing the Department to process outstanding and future liquidation requests without delay and to file a status report listing pending requests and processing timelines.

Appeal. The government noticed an interlocutory appeal (2d Cir. No. 25‑1424) and sought an immediate administrative stay and a stay pending appeal. On June 10, 2025, the Second Circuit denied an administrative stay and expedited the motion. On June 20, 2025, a motions panel denied a stay pending appeal. The panel concluded the district court likely had jurisdiction under the APA (analogizing to Bowen v. Massachusetts) rather than the Tucker Act, and that the states had shown a likelihood of success on their APA claims because the Department’s blanket rescission lacked a reasoned explanation and failed to consider reliance interests. The panel also found no showing of irreparable harm to the government and substantial injury to the states without relief; one judge dissented, favoring a stay. On August 11, 2025, the Second Circuit issued a mandate noting the parties’ stipulation withdrawing the appeal (FRAP 42). The district court later required the Department to continue status reporting; the Department has obtained extensions of time to answer, with the case proceeding on the merits.

Context and factual basis. The complaint details state‑level reliance on the extensions for ongoing, obligated projects, including tutoring and academic recovery services, mental‑health supports, homeless student services, and facility/HVAC projects. The states alleged immediate harms from the rescission, such as contractor layoffs, program shutdowns, and budget gaps, and asserted that Congress did not tie ESF availability to the duration of the public health emergency. The Department’s May 11 letter cited the end of the pandemic, concern that funds were being used less directly for student academic services, and a need for individualized review; it asserted no valid reliance interests existed but provided a brief wind‑down and a case‑by‑case extension process.

Key legal foundation.
- Cause of action: APA, 5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706 (arbitrary and capricious; contrary to law).
- Statutory/regulatory context: ARP and CRRSA appropriations; GEPA § 421 (Tydings); 2 C.F.R. § 200.344(c) (late liquidation authority).
- Remedy sought: declaratory judgment, vacatur, reinstatement of extensions through March 28, 2026, and injunctive relief.

Judge: District Judge Edgardo Ramos; Magistrate Judge Barbara C. Moses.

Decrees (preliminary injunctions).
- May 6, 2025: Enjoined the March 28 rescission; required 14‑day notice before any modification; Department to notify personnel and file a status report.
- June 3, 2025: Enjoined the March 28 and May 11 letters; barred modifications without 30‑day notice; ordered processing of liquidation requests without delay and a status report; $1,000 security; operative during the litigation.

Appeals: Second Circuit stay pending appeal denied June 20, 2025; appeal withdrawn August 11, 2025.

Counsel type: Plaintiffs by state Attorneys General; defendants by the U.S. Attorney’s Office, Southern District of New York.

Current posture: The preliminary injunction remains in place; the Department is processing liquidation requests under the injunction and filing status reports; defendants’ time to answer has been extended, and the case continues on the merits in the district court.

On May 27, 2025, National Public Radio, Inc. and three Colorado public radio stations (Roaring Fork Public Radio d/b/a Aspen Public Radio, Colorado Public Radio, and KUTE, Inc. d/b/a KSUT Public Radio) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia challenging Executive Order 14290, “Ending Taxpayer Subsidization of Biased Media,” issued by the President on May 1, 2025. The suit names as defendants the President (official capacity), the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, the Secretary of the Treasury, the Chair of the National Endowment for the Arts (substituted as Acting Chair Mary Anne Carter), OMB, the Department of the Treasury, the National Endowment for the Arts, and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (named solely to obtain complete relief). The case is before Judge Randolph D. Moss. Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel (Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP and Zansberg Beylkin LLC), with NPR also represented by in‑house counsel; the Federal Defendants are represented by the Department of Justice.

The case concerns Congress’s Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, which created the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) as a private, nonprofit entity to distribute federal funds for public broadcasting while insulating programming and CPB from government “direction, supervision, or control.” See 47 U.S.C. §§ 396, 398. By statute, CPB allocates most radio funds to local stations via Community Service Grants under neutral eligibility criteria (47 U.S.C. § 396(k)(6)(B)) and administers a separate Satellite Interconnection Fund to support national interconnection systems such as the Public Radio Satellite System (PRSS) (47 U.S.C. § 396(k)(10)). NPR manages and operates the PRSS as the national entity designated by interconnected public radio stations. Congress appropriated CPB general funding for FY 2025–2027 and interconnection funds for FY 2025 in recent appropriations laws. Separately, the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA) awards arts grants based on “artistic excellence and artistic merit,” considering “decency and respect.” 20 U.S.C. § 954(d)(1).

Plaintiffs allege the Executive Order directs CPB and all federal agencies to cease direct and indirect funding of NPR and PBS, to require CPB to prohibit local stations from using CPB funds to acquire NPR/PBS programming, and to revise CPB grant criteria accordingly. They contend the Order was issued to punish and deter NPR’s speech the Administration deems “biased,” citing the Order’s text and accompanying White House “Fact Sheet” and press release. Plaintiffs also recount prior public statements by the President criticizing NPR/PBS and an April 28, 2025 attempt to remove three CPB board members, which led CPB and others to file related litigation (Corporation for Public Broadcasting v. Trump, No. 25‑cv‑1305 (D.D.C.)). After the Order, NEA terminated an NPR grant the next day; Federal Defendants respond that NEA had two NPR grants that were fully paid in February 2025 and scheduled to expire May 31, 2025, and that termination effective May 31 did not withhold funds. Plaintiffs assert the Order chills their speech and interferes with member stations’ editorial choices and association with NPR. They also note subsequent developments, including CPB issuing a July 14, 2025 request for proposals seeking a new entity to manage and govern public radio content distribution and a quo warranto action filed by the government to oust CPB board members the President had purported to remove. Plaintiffs further represent that Congress later enacted a rescission of CPB appropriations for FY 2026 and FY 2027 at the President’s request.

Claims and legal basis. Plaintiffs bring constitutional and statutory claims, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief and vacatur of any agency actions implementing the Order:
- Cause of action and remedies: Equitable claims to enjoin unconstitutional and ultra vires actions by federal officials; Administrative Procedure Act (APA) review of any final agency actions implementing the Order (e.g., NEA terminations). Relief sought includes declaratory judgment that the Order and implementing actions are unlawful; preliminary and permanent injunctions barring implementation (with plaintiffs’ motion seeking an injunction against all defendants except the President); and vacatur of any final agency actions implementing the Order; plus fees and costs.
- Constitutional claims: First Amendment retaliation (punishment for protected speech), viewpoint-based discrimination (conditioning/denying public funding because of viewpoint), and infringement of freedom of expressive association (pressuring stations not to affiliate with or license NPR content). Plaintiffs also assert Fifth Amendment due process violations (deprivation of statutory entitlements and eligibility without notice and opportunity to be heard; and vagueness because the Order turns on “fair” or “unbiased” content).
- Statutory and separation-of-powers claims: Ultra vires actions contrary to the Public Broadcasting Act, including the non-interference mandate (47 U.S.C. § 398(a)), CPB’s funding criteria and required allocations (47 U.S.C. § 396(k)(6)(B), (k)(3)), and mandatory PRSS interconnection funding to the designated national entity (47 U.S.C. § 396(k)(10)(D)(i)); violation of the National Foundation on the Arts and Humanities Act’s grant criteria (20 U.S.C. § 954(d)(1)); violation of appropriations laws and the Spending Clause by directing agencies to withhold duly appropriated funds; and separation-of-powers concerns.

Federal Defendants oppose on jurisdictional and merits grounds. They argue the case is unripe and there is no final agency action: CPB disputes presidential control and has not terminated funding; Treasury has not withheld CPB funds; NEA’s two NPR grants were fully paid before the Order and terminated effective their original expiration date; and there is no current Article III injury. They contend the President is not subject to APA review and that neither APA nor nonstatutory ultra vires review applies absent final agency action. On the merits, they assert that when government acts as a patron rather than regulator it may choose not to subsidize speech (citing Rust v. Sullivan, Agency for Int’l Development v. AOSI, NEA v. Finley, Ysursa v. Pocatello), that denial of funding is not First Amendment retaliation or viewpoint discrimination in this context, and that the Order does not infringe association rights because entities remain free to associate using non-federal funds. They also argue plaintiffs lack any cognizable property interest in grants or continued eligibility and that void-for-vagueness doctrine does not apply to funding choices. Statutorily, they argue the Order must be implemented “to the maximum extent allowed by law” and “consistent with applicable law,” that the PBA’s interconnection provision permits distribution to stations or a designated national entity, that NEA may consider the President’s policy direction within its statutory standards, and that appropriations to CPB are lump-sum without line-item mandates.

Plaintiffs moved for summary judgment on June 13, 2025, seeking a declaratory judgment and a permanent injunction against implementation of the Order. The Court entered an expedited briefing schedule. Multiple amici supported plaintiffs, including a coalition of states, the ACLU, and press organizations; the Court granted leave to file their briefs. Federal Defendants cross-moved for summary judgment on July 12, 2025. Plaintiffs filed a combined opposition and reply on July 25, 2025. CPB answered the complaint on July 31, 2025. No merits ruling has issued, and there are no reported opinions in this case to date.

Context and factual basis. Plaintiffs assert the Order was issued to punish and deter NPR’s reporting and programming the Administration deems “biased,” noting the Order’s text and White House materials criticizing specific NPR/PBS content and the President’s public calls to “defund” NPR and PBS. They allege the Order unlawfully directs CPB to stop funding NPR and to bar local public stations from using CPB grants to acquire NPR programming, compels revision of CPB grant criteria, and instructs federal agencies to terminate direct or indirect NPR/PBS funding. Plaintiffs contend this contravenes Congress’s design in the Public Broadcasting Act to fund private, editorially independent public media, and that cutting off CPB support and station payments would harm NPR’s operations (including PRSS management and emergency alerting) and local stations’ ability to deliver national programming, while chilling speech and association. Federal Defendants dispute ripeness and injury, emphasize that CPB has not implemented the Order, that Treasury has continued funding CPB, and that NEA’s terminations did not claw back funds; they argue the Order lawfully aligns federal subsidies with policy priorities without regulating private speech. Related litigation over CPB board removals (Corporation for Public Broadcasting v. Trump, No. 25‑cv‑1305) and subsequent government actions regarding CPB’s governance are referenced as context.

The plaintiffs seek declaratory and permanent injunctive relief against implementation of the Executive Order, a declaration that NEA and CPB may not withhold funding on the basis of the Order, and vacatur of any agency action implementing it. A hearing on summary judgment was requested after briefing concluded on August 8, 2025. No trial has been set, and there have been no appeals.

On April 3, 2025, six national labor unions representing federal employees sued in the Northern District of California to stop enforcement of a March 27, 2025 executive order entitled “Exclusions from Federal Labor‑Management Relations Programs” (Executive Order 14251). The plaintiffs are national unions for federal workers; the defendants are the President, the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM) and its acting director, and numerous federal departments and agencies and their heads (including State, Defense, Treasury, Veterans Affairs, Justice, Health and Human Services, Homeland Security, Interior, Energy, Agriculture, EPA, NSF, the International Trade Commission, GSA, Social Security, Labor, HUD, Transportation, and Education). Plaintiffs are represented by private counsel and union counsel.

The suit is not a class action. Plaintiffs bring federal‑question claims seeking declaratory and injunctive relief. They allege: (1) First Amendment retaliation and viewpoint discrimination; (2) ultra vires action exceeding the limits of 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b)(1) (part of the Federal Service Labor‑Management Relations Statute in Chapter 71 of Title 5) and violating separation of powers; (3) Fifth Amendment procedural due process violations in abrogating contractual rights without notice and opportunity to respond; (4) Fifth Amendment deprivation of property rights in federal collective bargaining agreements; and (5) Fifth Amendment equal protection (arbitrary and irrational classifications). They seek to enjoin the Executive Order and OPM guidance, prevent termination of collective bargaining agreements and grievance/arbitration processes, maintain dues deductions under 5 U.S.C. § 7115, stop further exclusions (including by Transportation), and bar agencies from proposing additional exclusions.

Plaintiffs assert that EO 14251 invoked 5 U.S.C. § 7103(b)(1) to exclude more than 40 departments, agencies, and subdivisions from Chapter 71 on national security grounds, and that an accompanying White House Fact Sheet targeted “hostile Federal unions” that had “declared war on President Trump’s agenda.” Plaintiffs also cite OPM’s March 27, 2025 memorandum directing covered agencies to cease bargaining, end grievance/arbitration participation, terminate dues allotments, reclaim union space and official time, and disregard contractual RIF provisions. Although OPM later issued FAQs telling agencies not to terminate CBAs pending litigation, plaintiffs provided evidence that some agencies began terminating CBAs and other rights, and that unions suffered severe dues losses and loss of representational capacity, which they say chills their protected speech.

Key filings and rulings:
- April 7, 2025: Plaintiffs filed an ex parte motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and order to show cause for a preliminary injunction. The Court denied ex parte TRO relief but treated the motion as a preliminary‑injunction request and set briefing. Amici (former senior national security officials and advisors and the Bar Association of the District of Columbia) were allowed to file.
- June 24, 2025: Judge James Donato granted a preliminary injunction enjoining implementation of Section 2 of EO 14251 against plaintiffs and their members, and required a $60,000 bond ($10,000 per plaintiff). American Fed’n of Gov’t Emps., AFL‑CIO v. Trump, 2025 WL 1755442 (N.D. Cal. June 24, 2025). The Court rejected the government’s argument that the Federal Labor Relations Authority had exclusive jurisdiction because the Order excluded the agencies from Chapter 71. On the merits, the Court found serious questions on the First Amendment claim based on the White House Fact Sheet’s statements about “hostile” unions and the scope of the exclusions, concluded plaintiffs showed likely irreparable harm (loss of dues, collective bargaining and grievance rights, office space, official time, and chilled speech), and held the balance of hardships and public interest favored preserving the status quo. The injunction was limited to Section 2 (domestic agency exclusions) and did not cover the Order’s separate foreign service exclusions.
- July 8, 2025: The district court denied the government’s motion to stay the injunction pending appeal.
- Appeal: Defendants noticed an appeal on June 26, 2025 (Ninth Circuit No. 25‑4014). The Ninth Circuit granted an administrative stay on July 10, 2025, and on August 1, 2025, granted a stay pending appeal (per curiam; Judges Owens, Bade, and Bress). The panel concluded the government made a strong showing of likely success on the First Amendment retaliation claim under the Mt. Healthy defense (that the same action would have been taken absent protected conduct), found irreparable harm from tying the government’s hands in the national security context, and held the equities and public interest favored a stay. Order, No. 25‑4014 (9th Cir. Aug. 1, 2025) (published). The stay leaves the preliminary injunction suspended pending appeal.

Judge:
- District Judge: James Donato (N.D. Cal.).

Legal foundation and context:
- Statutory framework: The Federal Service Labor‑Management Relations Statute (FSLMRS), 5 U.S.C. §§ 7101–7135 (Chapter 71), guarantees federal employees the right to organize and bargain, with limits and management rights. Section 7103(b)(1) allows the President to exclude agencies or subdivisions upon specific national security determinations.
- Executive action at issue: EO 14251 (Mar. 27, 2025) excluded entire departments and numerous agencies or subdivisions from Chapter 71; OPM guidance directed immediate cessation of bargaining and related practices; a White House Fact Sheet criticized “hostile Federal unions.” Plaintiffs allege retaliatory motive, due process violations, and ultra vires overreach. Defendants maintain the Order rests on national security assessments authorized by § 7103(b)(1).

Related cases (not consolidated):
- The government filed suit the same night in the Western District of Texas (Waco) against several local unions to declare that CBAs may be terminated under the Order.
- Other challenges to EO 14251 proceeded in the District of Columbia; the D.C. Circuit stayed two preliminary injunctions in related cases. The district court here took judicial notice of those proceedings but ruled independently.

Current status:
- No trial has occurred. The district court’s preliminary injunction (enjoining Section 2 of EO 14251 as to plaintiffs and their members) is stayed by the Ninth Circuit pending appeal. The district court vacated near‑term case management dates in light of the appeal. No settlement, decree, or monitor has been ordered.
