Filing date and parties. The case was filed on July 21, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island. The plaintiffs are nonprofit organizations that include statewide domestic- and sexual-violence coalitions from numerous states and Rhode Island-based homeless and youth-service providers. They receive and depend on federal grants to operate shelters, prevention programs, and housing services. The defendants are federal officials and agencies—specifically the Departments of Health and Human Services (HHS) and Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and the heads of those departments and certain HHS components—sued in their official capacities. The plaintiffs are represented by a mix of public-interest and private counsel, including Democracy Forward Foundation, Jacobson Lawyers Group PLLC, the ACLU Foundation of Rhode Island (as cooperating counsel), the National Women’s Law Center, and local private counsel. This is not a class action.

Factual basis and challenged policies. After several executive orders issued in January 2025, the agencies added new conditions to a range of federal grants. The plaintiffs allege that, to implement the executive orders, HUD and HHS imposed unlawful terms requiring, among other things: (1) that grantees not “use grant funds to promote ‘gender ideology’” as defined in Executive Order 14168; (2) that grantees certify that compliance with all federal anti‑discrimination laws is “material” to payment decisions for False Claims Act purposes and certify they operate no programs that violate those laws; (3) that grantees not use funds to “fund or promote elective abortions,” citing Executive Order 14182; (4) that grantees’ funded activities are governed by “all current Executive Orders”; and (5) for HHS/ACF awards, that grantees certify they do not, and will not, operate programs that “advance or promote DEI, DEIA, or discriminatory equity ideology.” The plaintiffs assert these conditions were applied across HUD’s Continuum of Care (CoC) program and, via HUD’s Office of Community Planning and Development, to other programs including Community Development Block Grants (CDBG), and across HHS components through HHS’s Grants Policy Statement and component-specific terms (including ACF and HRSA). The plaintiffs contend these conditions are vague, conflict with statutes and regulations that require serving “underserved” populations (including LGBTQ+ survivors) and HUD’s Equal Access Rule (24 C.F.R. § 5.106), and expose grantees to civil and criminal liability under the False Claims Act.

Legal foundation and claims. The plaintiffs bring claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. §§ 701–706, alleging the conditions exceed statutory authority, are contrary to law, conflict with existing regulations, are arbitrary and capricious, and were adopted without required procedure (including HUD’s own rulemaking procedures at 24 C.F.R. pt. 10). They also bring constitutional claims asserting violations of separation of powers and the Spending Clause, First Amendment compelled speech and viewpoint discrimination, and Fifth Amendment due process vagueness, and an ultra vires claim. The statutory and regulatory backdrop the plaintiffs invoke includes the McKinney‑Vento/CoC provisions, the ESG and CDBG statutes, HHS’s Rape Prevention and Education program (42 U.S.C. § 280b‑1b), the Family Violence Prevention and Services Act (FVPSA) and its implementing regulation barring gender-identity discrimination (45 C.F.R. § 1370.5), and the DELTA program, all of which, they argue, protect or require services for underserved and culturally specific populations. The plaintiffs seek declaratory relief, vacatur, and injunctive relief, including stays under 5 U.S.C. § 705, to prevent imposition or enforcement of the conditions and to nullify any already-included terms.

Judge. The case is before District Judge Melissa R. DuBose (Magistrate Judge Patricia A. Sullivan is also assigned).

Filings and proceedings; rulings to date. On July 21, 2025, the coalitions and service providers moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO). After a July 24 hearing, the court granted a TRO on July 28, 2025, finding a likelihood of success on the merits and irreparable harm. The order enjoined HUD and the HUD Secretary from requiring certain named organizations and their members, in connection with CoC grants, to agree to or be subject to four conditions: (1) the “gender ideology” funding ban; (2) the certification making anti-discrimination compliance “material” to payment decisions; (3) the “elective abortion” funding ban; and (4) the clause stating the grantee’s funded operations are governed by “all current Executive Orders.” The order also enjoined HHS, ACF, and their officials from requiring certain coalitions to accept the ACF “anti‑DEI” certification for FVPSA Coalition grants. The court required the agencies to notify their staffs and file compliance status reports.

On August 7, 2025, the court issued a Revised TRO expanding the covered HUD plaintiffs and again enjoining the same four HUD CoC conditions and the ACF anti‑DEI certification for FVPSA Coalition grants. Later that day, the court issued a Second Revised TRO that also applied the HUD injunction to Community Development Block Grants and added additional organizations to the covered HUD group. On August 20, 2025, the court entered a Third Revised TRO (HUD filed further compliance notices). The TRO, as amended, remains in effect pending further order to accommodate the briefing on preliminary relief. In all TRO orders, the court deferred ruling on challenges to HHS’s Grants Policy Statement because HHS issued a revised Grants Policy Statement on July 24, 2025, removing references to “DEI,” “DEIA+,” and “discriminatory gender ideology,” and the court requested an administrative record before addressing that issue.

On August 4, 2025, the coalitions moved for preliminary relief under 5 U.S.C. § 705 and for a preliminary injunction that would stay and enjoin broader sets of HUD and HHS policies (including HUD’s agency‑wide “executive orders” compliance clause and HUD Form 424‑B anti‑DEI certification, ACF’s anti‑DEI and Title IX certifications, and HRSA’s Title IX certification). Defendants opposed on August 18, 2025. The court set a preliminary‑injunction hearing for September 4, 2025. No reported opinions have issued.

Remedy sought. The coalitions ask the court to declare the conditions unlawful, vacate and set them aside, stay their operation under § 705, and permanently enjoin the agencies from including or enforcing them (or substantially similar terms) in notices of funding opportunity, grant agreements, and subawards.

Related matters. The complaint references other litigation and decisions, including Colorado v. HHS, 2025 WL 1426226 (D.R.I. May 16, 2025), and filings in King County v. Turner, No. 2:25‑cv‑00814 (W.D. Wash.), but this case has not been consolidated with any other case.

Johnson concluded that, in essence, the case seeks to compel payment or continuation of federal grant funds and therefore falls within the Tucker Act’s contract‑claims regime, placing jurisdiction in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, not a district court under the APA. The court relied on recent Supreme Court guidance indicating that district courts lack jurisdiction to order payment of money under the APA where the claim is contractual in nature and that such claims belong in the Court of Federal Claims. Congress created the NEVI Formula Program in the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA), Pub. L. 117-58, appropriating $5 billion (FY 2022–2026), to “remain available until expended,” to fund states’ deployment and maintenance of EV charging infrastructure via a mandatory formula tied to Federal-Aid Highway apportionments. IIJA requires the Secretary to distribute funds by formula and directs states to submit State Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Deployment Plans; it enumerates limited, procedural preconditions for withholding or withdrawing funds (e.g., failure to submit a plan or failure to carry out a plan, with notice, consultation, cure periods, and appeal). FHWA issued NEVI program guidance in 2022 and updated it in 2023 and 2024; it approved state plans for FY 2022–2025 and advised that funds were “available for obligation.”

On January 20, 2025, the President issued Executive Order No. 14154 (“Unleashing American Energy”), directing agencies to immediately pause disbursement of IIJA and IRA funds, including NEVI. On January 29, 2025, DOT issued Order 2100.7 setting new departmental policy priorities. On February 6, 2025, FHWA sent states a letter rescinding current and prior NEVI guidance, “suspending” approval of all state plans for all fiscal years, and barring any new obligations until new guidance issued and new plans were submitted and approved. The states allege this action effectively froze approximately $2.74 billion in unobligated NEVI funds and derailed state projects and procurements that had relied on prior approvals.

The plaintiff states brought claims under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), 5 U.S.C. § 706(2), alleging agency action in excess of statutory authority, arbitrary and capricious action, and action not in accordance with law and without observance of procedures required by law; constitutional claims alleging violation of the separation of powers and the Take Care Clause; and a common law ultra vires claim. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief, including vacatur, to restore plan approvals and prevent withholding of NEVI funds except as permitted by IIJA; they also sought fees under 28 U.S.C. § 2412.

The case is before Judge Tana Lin. The plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction on May 7, 2025; the Court heard argument on June 17, 2025. Relying on the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Impoundment Control Act (ICA), the Anti‑Deficiency Act and Purpose Act, and the Constitution, plaintiffs allege that the government unlawfully froze obligations and disbursements, issued stop‑work orders, and then mass‑terminated thousands of foreign‑aid awards—actions they say ignored Congress’s 2024 appropriations for foreign assistance and the statutory limits on impoundment. They seek declaratory and injunctive relief (including reinstatement of awards), mandamus, and an order requiring defendants to make appropriated funds available and to pay for work completed.

Within days of filing, plaintiffs moved for a TRO/preliminary injunction. On February 13, 2025, Judge Amir H. Ali (D.D.C.) granted a TRO in both this case and the related case AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition v. U.S. Department of State (No. 25‑cv‑400), enjoining implementation of the State/USAID pause directives and forbidding the suspension, pausing, or other prevention of obligation or disbursement for awards in existence as of January 19, 2025, and enjoining the issuance or enforcement of terminations, suspensions, or stop‑work orders as to those awards. The Court later enforced the TRO on February 25, 2025, ordering defendants to pay invoices and honor letter‑of‑credit drawdowns for work completed before February 13. The D.C. Circuit dismissed an appeal of the TRO enforcement order for lack of jurisdiction, and the Supreme Court denied the government’s application to vacate an administrative stay, leaving the enforcement order intact.

After a consolidated preliminary‑injunction hearing, the Court on March 10, 2025, granted a preliminary injunction in part. The Court held plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their APA challenge to the initial blanket suspension of funds (January 20–February 13) and on their constitutional separation‑of‑powers claim that the Executive had unlawfully impounded congressionally appropriated funds without following the ICA, and that the asserted foreign‑affairs authority could not override Congress’s exclusive power of the purse. The Court enjoined (1) giving effect to any terminations, suspensions, or stop‑work orders issued between January 20 and February 13, 2025; (2) withholding of payments or LOC drawdowns for work completed before February 13; and (3) unlawful impoundment, directing defendants to make available for obligation the full amount of foreign‑assistance funds appropriated in the 2024 Act. The Court declined to invalidate post‑TRO, award‑by‑award termination decisions on the record then presented. To facilitate compliance, the Court set a feasibility benchmark of roughly 300 payments per day and required status reports. It later denied the government’s request for an indicative ruling to dissolve the payments requirement as to non‑parties, and vacated an administrative stay it had entered while considering that motion.

On April 22, 2025, plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint expanding their claims. They allege the State Department and USAID executed “tranches” of mass terminations based on cursory spreadsheets and action memoranda signed by the Secretary, constituting pretextual, post hoc rationalizations for the earlier freeze; that the agencies are moving to retire USAID’s independent operations and shift or eliminate programs; and that defendants’ decisions to “shut down” congressionally mandated programs and to hold funds in reserve violate the ICA, Anti‑Deficiency Act, Purpose Act, and the 2024 Appropriations Act. The amended pleading asserts APA arbitrary-and-capricious and contrary‑to‑law claims; a stand‑alone separation‑of‑powers claim; ultra vires and mandamus claims; and (as to GHC plaintiffs) a procedural due‑process claim. Defendants moved to dismiss under Rules 12(b)(1) and 12(b)(6) on June 12, 2025; briefing was held in abeyance pending the appellate proceedings.

Appeals followed. The government appealed the preliminary injunction (Nos. 25‑5097/5098). On August 13, 2025, a D.C. Circuit panel vacated the impoundment portion of the injunction, holding plaintiffs lacked a cause of action to press that claim, with a dissent. On August 20, 2025, the en banc D.C. Circuit entered an order stating that “the preliminary injunction that requires the government to obligate the appropriated funds remains in effect,” and the district court denied the government’s motion for a partial stay pending mandate. As of the latest district‑court orders, defendants continue to file periodic status reports and to process payments for pre‑TRO work, while the obligation/impoundment and termination issues remain under active enforcement and appellate review.

Factual context: The record shows that, after Executive Order 14169, State and USAID paused obligations and disbursements and issued stop‑work orders, in some instances halting payment even for completed work. OMB issued a government‑wide pause memorandum (M‑25‑13) that was later enjoined in separate litigation. Within weeks, State and USAID announced tens of hundreds of suspensions and terminations. Plaintiffs submitted declarations detailing widespread program disruptions and financial distress (including staff furloughs/layoffs, shuttered offices, and stranded commodities) and later alleged that defendants intend to realign or retire substantial USAID functions and not obligate large portions of appropriated funds absent judicial relief.

Judge: Amir H. Ali (D.D.C.).  
Related/Consolidated: Proceedings coordinated with AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition v. U.S. Department of State (No. 25‑cv‑400) for TRO/PI relief; the D.C. Circuit consolidated the appeals (Nos. 25‑5097/5098).  
Relief to date: TRO (2/13/2025); TRO enforcement (2/25/2025); preliminary injunction (3/10/2025) with continuing enforcement orders and status‑reporting; government’s motion for an indicative ruling denied (5/13/2025). The D.C. Circuit panel vacated the impoundment portion (8/13/2025), followed by an en banc order leaving the obligation requirement in place pending further proceedings. The district court denied a motion for a partial stay pending mandate (8/25/2025). The government’s motion to dismiss the amended complaint remains pending, with briefing stayed awaiting appellate resolution.

On February 9, 2025, the National Treasury Employees Union filed this action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia (Case No. 1:25‑cv‑00381‑ABJ) against the Acting Director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), Russell Vought, in his official capacity. An amended complaint filed February 13 added the CFPB as a defendant and additional plaintiffs: the National Consumer Law Center, the NAACP, the Virginia Poverty Law Center, the CFPB Employee Association, and Pastor Eva Steege (later substituted by her estate). Plaintiffs are represented by Gupta Wessler LLP, Public Citizen Litigation Group, and NTEU counsel; defendants are represented by the Department of Justice’s Civil Division, Federal Programs Branch.

Plaintiffs alleged that after a change in administration, the CFPB’s leadership took steps to dismantle the agency in defiance of Congress’s mandate in the Dodd‑Frank Act, including a February 10, 2025 bureau‑wide “stop‑work” email; cancellation of dozens of contracts (including in Enforcement, Supervision, and Consumer Response); firing of probationary and term employees; closing CFPB’s headquarters for a week; and plans for mass reductions in force (RIFs). Plaintiffs asserted non‑statutory ultra vires claims grounded in separation‑of‑powers principles and Appointments Clause (FVRA) defects; and Administrative Procedure Act claims under 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A) and (C), contending defendants exceeded statutory authority, acted arbitrarily and capriciously, and sought to shut down the CFPB contrary to Title X of Dodd‑Frank and specific statutory duties (e.g., maintaining a consumer complaint function, HMDA reporting, and operating the Private Education Loan Ombudsman). They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prevent further shutdown actions and to preserve the Bureau’s statutorily required operations.

Following an emergency filing, the court (Judge Amy Berman Jackson) entered a consent order on February 14, 2025 preserving agency data, prohibiting terminations except for cause and notices of RIF, and preventing transfers of reserve funds pending resolution of the preliminary‑injunction motion. After briefing, a motions hearing (March 3) and two‑day evidentiary hearing (March 10–11) were held. The court received testimony from CFPB Chief Operating Officer Adam Martinez and others regarding the February 10 stop‑work directive, contract cancellations, plans for an accelerated RIF, and the practical shutdown of key functions (including Consumer Response).

On March 28, 2025, the court issued a memorandum opinion and preliminary injunction. It found plaintiffs likely to succeed on separation‑of‑powers and APA claims, concluding the record showed defendants had undertaken “a concerted, expedited effort to shut the agency down entirely,” contrary to Congress’s mandate. The order required defendants to: (1) preserve all CFPB records and data; (2) reinstate probationary and term employees terminated since February 10 (including the Private Student Loan Ombudsman); (3) refrain from terminating employees except for cause and from issuing RIF notices; (4) cease enforcing the February 10 stop‑work directive or achieving a work stoppage by other means (e.g., administrative leave edicts); (5) provide staff with office space or fully functional remote‑work capability; (6) ensure the Office of Consumer Response maintained the toll‑free number, website, and database and continued monitoring and responses, including escalated case management; and (7) rescind contract termination notices and refrain from finalizing further terminations absent individualized assessments that a contract was unnecessary to statutory functions. The court initially required a compliance report by April 4.

Defendants noticed an appeal to the D.C. Circuit and sought a stay. On April 11, 2025, the D.C. Circuit partially stayed the injunction pending appeal, permitting terminations or RIFs, and targeted work stoppages, only after “particularized assessments” that affected employees or work were unnecessary to statutory duties, and staying the compliance‑report provision. The court of appeals expedited the appeal for argument on May 16.

On April 17, 2025, defendants issued mass RIF notices to approximately 1,400–1,500 employees. Plaintiffs moved for an order to show cause; the district court held a hearing on April 18 and temporarily suspended the RIF and prohibited cutting off system access pending an evidentiary hearing, citing likely noncompliance with the injunction. Defendants appealed. On April 28, 2025, the D.C. Circuit clarified that a “particularized assessment” must determine, by the decisionmaker responsible for the RIF, that each CFPB division could perform statutorily required duties without the employees subject to RIF; and, sua sponte, lifted its partial stay of paragraph (3) of the preliminary injunction, restoring the district court’s blanket prohibition on RIFs to ensure meaningful final relief, while keeping other provisions as previously stayed.

Separately, a related appeal of the April 18 interim order was voluntarily dismissed as moot on May 12, 2025. On the merits appeal, the D.C. Circuit issued its decision on August 15, 2025, vacating the preliminary injunction and remanding. The court held that claims by the employee‑representative plaintiffs were channeled by the Civil Service Reform Act and thus outside district‑court jurisdiction; that the NAACP had associational standing; that plaintiffs’ APA claims failed because they did not target discrete, final agency action (the February 10 email was not final action, and the alleged “shutdown decision” was not a final, ripe, or discrete action under the APA); and that plaintiffs’ equitable separation‑of‑powers claim sounded in statutory ultra vires rather than a freestanding constitutional cause of action under Dalton v. Specter. Judge Pillard dissented.

Key statutory context throughout was Title X of the Dodd‑Frank Act (12 U.S.C. § 5491 et seq.), which created the CFPB, assigned it rulemaking, supervision, enforcement, and specific mandatory duties (including consumer complaint intake and response, reporting obligations, and specialized offices), and established its funding outside annual appropriations. The district court’s March 28 injunction preserved those functions pending appeal; the D.C. Circuit’s April 11 and April 28 orders adjusted interim relief; and the August 15 appellate opinion vacated the injunction and returned the case for further proceedings consistent with its rulings.

Filed on March 28, 2012, Ligon v. City of New York is a civil‑rights class action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 brought by residents and visitors of private apartment buildings in New York City—principally in the Bronx—challenging the New York City Police Department’s implementation of “Operation Clean Halls,” later formalized as the Trespass Affidavit Program (TAP). Plaintiffs, represented by the New York Civil Liberties Union, The Bronx Defenders, LatinoJustice PRLDEF, New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, and pro bono counsel from Shearman & Sterling, alleged systematic Fourth Amendment seizures and frisks without reasonable suspicion and Fourteenth Amendment equal protection violations, arising from NYPD stops in and around TAP buildings based solely on presence, entry, or exit. Defendants were the City of New York, the Police Commissioner, and individual officers.

After expedited discovery and a six‑day evidentiary hearing, Judge Shira A. Scheindlin granted a preliminary injunction on January 8, 2013 (amended February 14, 2013), finding a clear likelihood plaintiffs would prove the City’s deliberate indifference to a widespread practice of unconstitutional trespass stops outside TAP buildings in the Bronx. The court certified, for purposes of preliminary relief, a Rule 23(b)(2) class of “[a]ll individuals who have been or are at risk of being stopped outdoors within the vicinity of Bronx apartment buildings enrolled in the NYPD’s [TAP] without legal justification” (Feb. 11, 2013). On August 12, 2013, the court issued a Remedies Opinion in Floyd and Ligon ordering systemic reforms: revising NYPD policies on investigative encounters (clarifying what constitutes a Terry stop, the reasonable‑suspicion standard, and that a frisk requires separate reasonable suspicion that a person is armed and dangerous), prohibiting racial profiling, improving training and supervision, auditing, and instituting a one‑year body‑worn camera (BWC) pilot, as well as a community‑based Joint Remedial Process. A court‑appointed independent monitor, Peter L. Zimroth, was tasked with developing, overseeing, and reporting on implementation; Nicholas Turner and later Justice Ariel E. Belen served as facilitators for the Joint Remedial Process.

The City appealed the preliminary injunction and remedial orders. On October 31, 2013, the Second Circuit stayed the district court’s orders and reassigned the cases, but on February 21, 2014, it granted a limited remand to explore settlement. The City subsequently withdrew its appeals; the cases were reassigned to Judge Analisa Torres, who modified the remedial order to define “substantial compliance” and set the monitor’s minimum tenure (no sooner than three years after approval of reforms, contingent on the City’s showing of substantial compliance) (July 30, 2014). Procedures were set for submitting and approving the monitor’s recommendations (2015), and the BWC pilot was refined (Dec. 8, 2015).

On July 19, 2017, the parties executed a Stipulation of Settlement and Order that fully resolved Ligon. Without admitting liability, the City agreed to adopt and implement detailed standards for enforcement in and around TAP buildings and to incorporate oversight under the Floyd/Ligon remedial monitoring. The settlement tightened NYPD rules so that mere presence in, entry into, or exit from a TAP building cannot justify a Level 1 approach, a Level 2 accusatory inquiry, or a Level 3 stop; required documentation of every Level 3 stop (including narrative articulation of reasonable suspicion and, separately, grounds for any frisk or search); required probable cause for arrests or summonses; prohibited frisks absent reasonable suspicion that a person is armed and dangerous; and mandated completion of a standardized Trespass Crimes Fact Sheet prior to arraignment for every trespass arrest in or around a TAP building. The NYPD agreed to revise Patrol Guide § 212‑59 (interior patrols of TAP buildings) and Administrative Guide § 303‑27 (TAP administration), including enrollment and periodic renewal criteria tied to crime or complaints and higher‑level approvals for extended participation. The Department committed to training all personnel engaged in TAP enforcement and TAP administration on these standards, and to provide roll‑call, in‑service, promotional, and recruit training consistent with the revised policies (including the investigative encounters policy, P.G. 212‑11, and the racial profiling policy, P.G. 203‑25). The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the settlement, incorporated the Floyd remedial monitoring (with substantial‑compliance benchmarks), and provided for a second remedial phase of document production and review following the monitor’s tenure. The City agreed to pay $235,000 in damages to named plaintiffs and to pay class counsel’s reasonable fees and costs ($2,585,101 in fees and $55,432 in costs through June 30, 2016, plus additional negotiated interim fees).

Under oversight by Monitor Zimroth, the NYPD issued and implemented revised policies on investigative encounters (P.G. 212‑11) and racial profiling (P.G. 203‑25), and adopted the court‑approved Trespass Crimes Fact Sheet. The monitor launched a randomized BWC pilot in patrol precincts and a quasi‑experimental BWC evaluation in Housing Bureau PSAs, and reported on implementation, training, supervision, auditing, and performance‑evaluation changes, including NYPD’s RISKS Reviews to address underreporting and supervisory shortcomings. Subsequent orders facilitated the monitor’s recommendations and implementation (e.g., a 2019 confidentiality order for an observational study, and a 2020 order establishing an interagency adverse‑findings early‑intervention program). Throughout, the court also managed related proceedings in the companion cases Floyd v. City of New York (general stop‑and‑frisk) and Davis v. City of New York (NYCHA housing), with Ligon’s monitoring integrated into the combined remedial process.

Judge Scheindlin presided through the preliminary‑injunction and remedies phase; Judge Torres has overseen the settlement and monitoring. The Second Circuit’s October 31, 2014 opinion affirmed denial of police unions’ motions to intervene and dismissed the City’s appeals, allowing the remedial process to proceed. The court retains jurisdiction under the settlement until substantial compliance is achieved and maintained per the agreed terms.

Filed on November 9, 2010, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut, this non‑class civil action was brought by several same‑sex couples lawfully married in Connecticut, Vermont, and New Hampshire and by the surviving spouse of a same‑sex marriage. The plaintiffs challenged Section 3 of the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), 1 U.S.C. § 7, insofar as it required the federal government to disregard their state‑law marriages and deny them marital status and benefits under federal law. The defendants were federal agencies and officials responsible for administering programs that hinge on marital status—including the Office of Personnel Management, the Secretaries of the Treasury and Labor, the Commissioner of Social Security, the U.S. Postal Service and the Postmaster General, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, the Attorney General, the Comptroller of the Currency, and the United States. After the Department of Justice notified Congress on February 23, 2011, that the Executive would no longer defend Section 3’s constitutionality, the Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group of the U.S. House of Representatives (BLAG) intervened to defend the statute. Plaintiffs were represented by Gay & Lesbian Advocates & Defenders (a public‑interest legal organization) and private firms; the government defendants by the Department of Justice; and BLAG by House Counsel and private counsel.

The plaintiffs asserted a federal question and sought declaratory and injunctive relief under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 2201–2202 (and program‑specific judicial review statutes including 5 U.S.C. § 8912, 29 U.S.C. § 2617(a)(2), and 42 U.S.C. § 405(g)). Their legal theory was that DOMA Section 3, as applied to them, violated the equal protection component of the Fifth Amendment by denying federal recognition of valid state marriages and the spousal benefits and obligations that follow. Specific remedies included declarations that Section 3 is unconstitutional as applied, injunctions against its enforcement with respect to federal benefits, and, for the tax‑filing couples, appropriate refunds (with the United States named under 26 U.S.C. § 7422(f)(1)).

The factual basis of the case showed concrete denials flowing from DOMA’s marriage definition across multiple federal programs: (1) a retired federal civilian employee and her wife were barred from converting Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) coverage to “Self & Family” to cover the spouse; (2) a Postal Service employee was denied Family and Medical Leave Act leave to care for her wife and the couple was refused FEHB “Self & Family” coverage; (3) a widower was denied both the Social Security one‑time lump‑sum death benefit and a qualified preretirement survivor annuity under an ERISA‑governed defined‑benefit plan because his marriage was not recognized; (4) two retired New Hampshire teachers were denied a spousal medical cost supplement from the state retirement system because federal tax law (as applied through DOMA) limited § 401(h) retiree medical benefits to opposite‑sex “spouses”; (5) two married couples were denied the right to file joint federal income tax returns (and resulting refunds); and (6) a federal attorney was denied the ability to add his husband to existing FEHB family coverage, forcing purchase of private insurance.

Judge Vanessa L. Bryant denied BLAG’s request to stay proceedings pending the Second Circuit’s decision in a related DOMA appeal (Windsor) and on July 31, 2012, granted plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment, denying BLAG’s motion to dismiss. In a published memorandum (2012 WL 3113883), the court held that Baker v. Nelson’s summary disposition did not control because this case challenged a federal statute applied to already‑valid state marriages, not a state’s authority to issue marriage licenses. The court concluded that sexual orientation classifications warrant heightened scrutiny but found it unnecessary to apply that standard because Section 3 failed even rational basis review. The court rejected Congress’s and BLAG’s proffered justifications—defending “traditional” marriage; promoting responsible procreation and child‑rearing; moral disapproval; conserving resources; federal “uniformity”; and “caution”—as either impermissible, not legitimate in this context, or not rationally related to Section 3’s across‑the‑board denial of recognition to one subset of state‑sanctioned marriages. The court entered judgment declaring Section 3 unconstitutional as applied to the plaintiffs and enjoining its enforcement against them.

Key filings included plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment (July 15, 2011); BLAG’s motion to dismiss (August 15, 2011); and the Attorney General’s notification to Congress ending executive defense of Section 3, prompting BLAG’s permitted intervention (May 27, 2011). Reported decision: Pedersen v. Office of Pers. Mgmt., 2012 WL 3113883 (D. Conn. July 31, 2012). BLAG’s motion to stay was denied on July 4, 2012. The federal defendants filed a notice of appeal on August 17, 2012, and BLAG noticed a separate appeal on September 26, 2012, to the Second Circuit. While those appeals were pending, plaintiffs and the federal defendants each petitioned the Supreme Court for a writ of certiorari before judgment; BLAG opposed, urging review in related cases instead. The district court proceedings concluded with the summary judgment and final judgment; no trial occurred.

On May 28, 2015, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ), Civil Rights Division, filed suit under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997, against the State of Alabama and the Alabama Department of Corrections (ADOC) to enjoin ongoing deprivation of prisoners’ constitutional rights at the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women. The complaint alleged that, through acts and omissions, the State subjected women at Tutwiler to sexual abuse and sexual harassment in violation of the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment. DOJ’s allegations rested on a 2013–2014 investigation and a January 17, 2014 findings letter, which documented a longstanding, pervasive “sexualized environment” that included staff rape and coerced sexual activity, voyeurism and cross‑gender viewing, sexually explicit verbal abuse, pregnancies caused by staff, underreporting and inadequate investigations, retaliation against women who reported abuse (including segregation and lie‑detector tests), dangerously low staffing and supervision, lack of a grievance system, and facilities and practices that failed to protect women from harm.

The same day DOJ filed its complaint, the parties jointly moved for entry of a negotiated settlement as a court order. On June 18, 2015, Judge Myron H. Thompson approved the agreement as a consent decree, conditionally dismissed the case without prejudice, and retained jurisdiction to enforce the decree and resolve disputes. The court found the relief complied with the Prison Litigation Reform Act: it was narrowly drawn, extended no further than necessary to correct the constitutional violation, and was the least intrusive means. The decree contemplated that defendants would implement required policies and practices within nine months, be subject to independent monitoring and semiannual compliance reporting, and achieve and maintain substantial compliance with each provision for three consecutive monitor reports (18 months) before termination.

The consent decree requires system‑wide reforms at Tutwiler to prevent, detect, and respond to sexual abuse and harassment. Significant terms include:
- Zero‑tolerance PREA compliance: adopt and implement policies meeting the Prison Rape Elimination Act standards; provide comprehensive initial and annual refresher training for all staff, contractors, and volunteers; and educate all inmates at intake and in orientation about their rights, reporting methods, and access to medical/mental health care.
- Reporting and grievance systems: create multiple, unimpeded reporting avenues (verbal, written, anonymous, third‑party), including an external, confidential hotline administered by the Alabama Department of Economic and Community Affairs (ADECA) and access to the Alabama Coalition Against Rape for confidential support; implement a formal inmate grievance system (including emergency grievances for imminent risk) that prohibits retaliation; and ensure prompt documentation and response to reports.
- Investigations and discipline: conduct prompt, thorough, objective investigations (with trained investigators, appropriate evidence handling, and inmate notifications); refer substantiated staff sexual abuse to prosecutors; and track and impose appropriate staff discipline.
- Privacy and searches: prohibit cross‑gender strip and visual body cavity searches absent exigent circumstances; prohibit cross‑gender pat‑downs of women absent exigent circumstances; restrict cross‑gender viewing of inmates who are nude or performing bodily functions; require opposite‑sex staff to announce their presence; and address architectural features to enhance privacy.
- LGBTI/transgender protections: adopt gender‑responsive policies for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, and gender‑nonconforming inmates; ensure appropriate clothing, hygiene, shower access, respectful communication (including pronoun use), and clinical care.
- Staffing and supervision: develop and implement a gender‑responsive staffing plan (including identification of gender‑specific posts), a shift‑relief factor, and procedures for unannounced rounds; install and manage a state‑of‑the‑art camera system to supplement, not replace, physical rounds; recruit and retain women officers; and review the Alabama Peace Officers’ Standards and Training Commission (APOSTC) physical standards for validation and potential gender‑norming.
- Classification and risk assessment: implement a gender‑responsive classification system and the Women’s Risk/Needs Assessment (WRNA); screen all inmates at intake and within 30 days for risk of victimization/abusiveness; use screening results to inform individualized housing, bed, work, program, and education assignments; limit use of involuntary segregation for protection; and abolish “restricted status.”
- Quality improvement and data: establish a Risk Management System (RMS) and quality improvement program to collect, analyze, and act on data regarding sexual abuse/harassment incidents, unprofessional staff conduct (including sexually explicit, vulgar, degrading, or racially insensitive/offensive language), and use‑of‑force incidents; conduct regular inmate polling; and perform periodic reviews to identify trends and corrective actions.
- Basic needs: ensure free and adequate access to essential hygiene supplies (including tampons and pads), uniforms, and linens.

Monitoring has been continuous. The court appointed an independent monitor to oversee implementation and file semiannual reports. The first monitor (Jennie Lancaster) reported in February 2016 that ADOC and Tutwiler had achieved substantial compliance with many provisions (e.g., inmate education, hygiene supplies, camera management, initial PREA policy development and training) and partial compliance with others (notably the staffing plan and development of gender‑responsive use‑of‑force and discipline policies). In August 2016, Kathleen Dennehy became monitor and has filed regular reports. By March 2017 and through 2019, the monitor consistently found substantial compliance in most areas, with improvements including: widespread PREA and refresher training; robust inmate education and orientation; functioning internal and external reporting systems (ADECA hotline and third‑party reporting); a PREA‑trained investigations unit with timely, policy‑compliant investigations; expanded cameras and annual camera reviews; cross‑gender privacy and search policies implemented facility‑wide; gender‑responsive LGBTI policies and practices; a functioning grievance system; a quality improvement program and RMS with biannual and annual reviews; and implementation of the WRNA and women’s programming (e.g., Helping Women Recover, Beyond Trauma, Beyond Violence, Active Adult Relationships, Moving On, Parenting Inside Out, and reentry programming). The monitor reported that women generally felt sexually safe, knew how to report, and expressed confidence in the PREA investigator and the Institutional PREA Compliance Manager.

Two persistent challenges remained. First, correctional staffing: despite a finalized staffing plan (July 2017) and implementation of many of its recommendations (including shift changes, recruitment initiatives, and overtime controls), Tutwiler continued to have significant officer vacancies, requiring overtime, post “doubling,” and occasional use of supervisors in line posts. Recruitment and retention of women officers, validation of APOSTC standards, and long‑term staffing sufficiency remained in partial compliance. Second, aspects of facility culture: while sexual abuse and harassment declined, inmate polling and RMS data continued to identify a small number of staff using profane, degrading, or racially insensitive language; the administration responded with reminders, coaching, and training (including Racial Intelligence Training and Engagement) and progressive discipline where substantiated.

The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the consent decree, which remains in effect until the State achieves and sustains substantial compliance with all provisions for three consecutive monitor reports. No appeals were taken. The DOJ was represented by the Civil Rights Division, Special Litigation Section and the U.S. Attorney’s Office; the State and ADOC were represented by ADOC’s General Counsel.
results.ED-MI-0001:
On November 8, 2006, the day after Michigan voters approved “Proposal 2” amending the state constitution to prohibit public institutions from discriminating against or granting preferential treatment based on race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin in public higher education, employment, and contracting (Mich. Const. art. I, § 26), several organizations and individuals filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan. The plaintiffs included civil‑rights groups (BAMN, UEAALDF, Rainbow PUSH), unions, students, prospective applicants, and a student political party. They sued the Governor and the governing boards of the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, and Wayne State University, later adding the Michigan Attorney General as a defendant and asserting claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. They alleged violations of the Equal Protection Clause—both as intentional discrimination and under the “political structure” doctrine of Hunter v. Erickson and Washington v. Seattle School Dist. No. 1—preemption by Titles VI, VII, and IX, and infringement of universities’ First Amendment academic freedom, and sought declaratory and injunctive relief barring enforcement of Proposal 2.

On December 11, 2006, the university defendants filed a cross‑claim for declaratory relief and a preliminary injunction to postpone Proposal 2’s effective date during the then‑ongoing admissions cycle. The district court entered a stipulated temporary injunction on December 19, 2006, delaying application of § 26 to university admissions and financial aid through June 30, 2007, but the Sixth Circuit stayed that order on December 29, 2006 (Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action v. Granholm, 473 F.3d 237 (6th Cir. 2006)). The Attorney General intervened as a defendant; the court permitted Eric Russell, a Michigan law‑school applicant, to intervene and denied other intervention motions. A related action, Cantrell v. Granholm, filed December 19, 2006 by students and faculty asserting a political‑process equal protection claim focused on public university admissions, was consolidated on January 5, 2007. Plaintiffs also moved for class certification of student and faculty classes.

On March 18, 2008, Judge David M. Lawson granted summary judgment to the Attorney General, upheld Proposal 2, and denied the Cantrell plaintiffs’ summary judgment motion (Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action v. Regents of the Univ. of Mich., 539 F. Supp. 2d 924 (E.D. Mich. 2008)). The court rejected the “political structure” challenge, distinguishing Hunter and Seattle on the ground that § 26 banned preferential treatment rather than obstructing access to equal treatment, and dismissed the First Amendment “academic freedom” claim for lack of standing. It denied the universities’ motion to dismiss themselves as unnecessary parties, reasoning their actions would be required to afford relief if the amendment fell. In a separate order that day, the court granted the Cantrell plaintiffs’ motion for summary judgment as to intervenor Russell and dismissed him (Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action v. Regents of the Univ. of Mich., 539 F. Supp. 2d 960 (E.D. Mich. 2008)); it later denied reconsideration (592 F. Supp. 2d 948 (E.D. Mich. 2008)).

The plaintiffs appealed. A Sixth Circuit panel reversed, holding Proposal 2 unconstitutional under the Equal Protection Clause’s political‑process doctrine (652 F.3d 607 (6th Cir. 2011)), but the court granted rehearing en banc, vacated the panel opinion, and on November 15, 2012 again reversed the district court, concluding that § 26 unconstitutionally restructured the political process by removing authority over race‑conscious admissions from elected university boards and placing it at the state‑constitutional level, thereby imposing special burdens on racial minorities (Coal. to Defend Affirmative Action v. Regents of the Univ. of Mich., 701 F.3d 466 (6th Cir. 2012)). The en banc court also affirmed the district court’s refusal to dismiss the universities as parties and affirmed dismissal of intervenor Russell.

The Michigan Attorney General petitioned for certiorari. On April 22, 2014, the U.S. Supreme Court reversed, holding there is no federal constitutional basis to set aside a state constitutional amendment that commits to voters the decision whether race‑based preferences may be considered in governmental decisions—including university admissions—and that Hunter and Seattle did not compel a different result in this context (Schuette v.
