results.DR-CA-0033:
On August 22, 2005, a wheelchair user sued a national restaurant chain in the Southern District of California under Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), 42 U.S.C. § 12181 et seq., and California access laws (the Unruh Civil Rights Act and the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA)). The plaintiff alleged that two newly constructed Chipotle Mexican Grill restaurants in San Diego (Pacific Beach) and Encinitas denied him full and equal enjoyment of their goods and services. He cited inaccessible parking, entrances, and restrooms, and principally challenged a 44-inch wall (46 inches with sneeze guard bracket) along the food preparation counter that blocked wheelchair users—whose average eye level is 43–51 inches—from seeing the food being prepared and displayed, which he argued was central to the “Chipotle experience.” He sought declaratory and injunctive relief and damages under state law.

At the time of the visits (2005–2006), Chipotle had an unwritten practice of accommodating customers with disabilities by holding up serving spoons or cups of food or moving food to a side counter or table; in February 2007, it adopted a written “Customers With Disabilities” policy to formalize such accommodations. After contested discovery (including a third‑party indemnity claim by Chipotle against its landlords over common‑area obligations that was later dismissed), the court (Judge Napoleon A. Jones, Jr.) granted in part and denied in part cross‑motions for summary judgment on June 14, 2007. The court held that the food area was governed by ADAAG § 7.2 (sales and service counters), not § 4.33.3 (fixed seating/assembly areas). It found Chipotle’s lowered transaction station did not satisfy § 7.2(2)(i) or (ii), and set for trial the question whether Chipotle provided “equivalent facilitation” under § 7.2(2)(iii). The court also found ADA violations in the parking lots during some of the plaintiff’s visits but, because those had been corrected, dismissed the ADA claims as moot and reserved CDPA damages; ADA claims regarding entrances, restrooms, and seating were resolved or deemed outside the pleadings.

Following a four‑day bench trial in November–December 2007, the court ruled that Chipotle’s unwritten practice of accommodation did not constitute equivalent facilitation but that its 2007 written policy did. The court denied injunctive relief and awarded $5,000 in CDPA statutory damages ($1,000 per visit) for five “bona fide” visits before the written policy; it denied damages for three visits undertaken primarily to gather evidence. On April 21, 2008, it denied the plaintiff’s motion to amend the findings. The court later awarded the plaintiff $136,537.83 in attorneys’ fees; each side bore its own costs.

Both sides appealed. In a published decision, Antoninetti v. Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc., 643 F.3d 1165 (9th Cir. 2010), the Ninth Circuit (Judges Friedman, D.W. Nelson, and Reinhardt) affirmed that § 7.2 governs Chipotle’s counters and that the lowered transaction station was not a “portion” of the main counter or an auxiliary counter under § 7.2(2)(i) or (ii). It reversed the district court’s ruling that the written policy constituted equivalent facilitation under § 7.2(2)(iii), holding that showing samples or assembling food at another location did not provide “substantially equivalent or greater access to and usability of the facility.” The court concluded that Chipotle violated the ADA, vacated the denial of injunctive relief as an abuse of discretion, and remanded for entry of an appropriate injunction. It also vacated the damages award and remanded for further proceedings, noting that damages under the CDPA are available for visits when the plaintiff “actually presented himself … with the intent of being served and to purchase food … and actually encountered” unequal access. The Ninth Circuit vacated the fee award and directed reconsideration in light of the changed outcome.

On remand before Judge Barry Ted Moskowitz, the court entered judgment for the plaintiff on the ADA violation and set proceedings on injunctive relief and damages. Chipotle represented that it had lowered food preparation counters at all California restaurants; the court permitted limited discovery to evaluate mootness and how to ensure permanent compliance. Before injunctive relief could be fashioned, the plaintiff passed away on May 9, 2011. On March 21, 2012, the court denied injunctive relief as moot and awarded $5,000 in CDPA damages for five “bona fide” visits; it again denied damages for three litigation‑related visits under the Ninth Circuit’s guidance. The court later reconsidered fees and, in 2012, awarded substantially increased fees (over $500,000) and costs for district court work and for successfully opposing Chipotle’s petition for a writ of certiorari; the Ninth Circuit separately awarded appellate fees. Throughout the case, the plaintiff was represented by private counsel, and Chipotle by private counsel. Related litigation included a later‑filed statewide class action (Antoninetti et al. v. Chipotle, No. 06‑cv‑2671 (S.D. Cal.)), which was consolidated with this case for discovery.
results.CJ-FL-0009:
In June 2019, several lawsuits were filed in the Northern District of Florida and later consolidated as Jones v. DeSantis (No. 4:19‑cv‑300). The individual plaintiffs were Florida residents with past felony convictions who had completed incarceration and supervision but still owed court-imposed financial obligations; organizational plaintiffs were the Florida State Conference of the NAACP, the Orange County Branch of the NAACP, and the League of Women Voters of Florida, which conduct voter registration and education. The defendants were the Governor of Florida, the Florida Secretary of State (the state’s chief election officer), and several county Supervisors of Elections. Plaintiffs were represented by civil-rights organizations and private counsel, including the ACLU, Brennan Center for Justice, Campaign Legal Center, NAACP Legal Defense Fund, and the Southern Poverty Law Center.

Proceeding under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, the plaintiffs challenged Senate Bill 7066—enacted after Florida voters approved Amendment 4 in November 2018—which defined “completion of all terms of sentence” to include payment of fines, fees, costs, and restitution. They alleged (i) wealth-based discrimination in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment’s Equal Protection Clause; (ii) an unconstitutional “poll tax or other tax” under the Twenty-Fourth Amendment; (iii) violations of the Due Process Clause due to vagueness and the risk of erroneous deprivation of the right to vote; and (iv) related statutory claims (including the National Voter Registration Act and, in some complaints, the Voting Rights Act). They sought declaratory and injunctive relief and class certification.

On October 18, 2019, after a two-day evidentiary hearing, Judge Robert L. Hinkle granted a preliminary injunction preventing the Secretary of State and certain county supervisors from barring the 17 individual plaintiffs from registering or voting based solely on unpaid LFOs if they asserted (for registration) or showed (for voting) that they were genuinely unable to pay. The court rejected a request to abstain and noted the Florida Supreme Court would soon address the state-law meaning of Amendment 4. On February 19, 2020, the Eleventh Circuit affirmed the preliminary injunction (950 F.3d 795), holding that heightened scrutiny applied to wealth-based discrimination in this context and that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their Equal Protection claim as applied to those unable to pay.

Meanwhile, on January 16, 2020, the Florida Supreme Court issued an advisory opinion construing Amendment 4 to require payment of all financial obligations imposed as part of the sentence. Back in the district court, Judge Hinkle certified a class (all otherwise-eligible persons denied the right to vote because of outstanding LFOs) and a subclass (those genuinely unable to pay) on April 7, 2020. Following an eight‑day bench trial in April 2020, the court issued a merits decision on May 24, 2020 (2020 WL 2618062). Based on extensive factual findings—including that Florida lacked a reliable process to determine what LFOs were owed and paid, and that most affected individuals were indigent—the court held that Florida could not condition voting on LFOs a person was genuinely unable to pay; that court fees and costs functioned as “other taxes” barred by the Twenty-Fourth Amendment; and that the State’s implementation created a substantial risk of erroneous deprivation and deterred lawful voting. The court permanently enjoined enforcement of SB 7066 to the extent it (1) required payment of fees and costs as a condition of voting, (2) required payment of fines or restitution that a person genuinely could not pay, or (3) required payment of amounts that could not be determined with diligence. It also ordered a streamlined advisory‑opinion process through the Division of Elections to confirm eligibility or inability to pay.

The Governor and Secretary appealed. On July 16, 2020, the Supreme Court denied an application to vacate an appellate stay; Justice Sotomayor, joined by Justices Ginsburg and Kagan, dissented. On September 11, 2020, sitting en banc, the Eleventh Circuit reversed (975 F.3d 1016), vacated the injunction, and upheld SB 7066. The majority held that rational-basis review applies to felon reenfranchisement classifications; that requiring completion of all sentencing terms, including LFOs, is rationally related to legitimate state interests; that court‑imposed fees and costs are punitive, not “taxes,” and therefore do not violate the Twenty-Fourth Amendment; and that Florida’s procedures—including notice and hearings before removal from the rolls and an advisory‑opinion mechanism—did not violate due process or render the scheme void for vagueness. The court also rejected arguments that the State’s administrative difficulties in determining LFO balances rendered the law unconstitutional.

Key proceedings included: (1) preliminary injunction granted October 18, 2019 (N.D. Fla.); (2) partial stay of the injunction pending appeal December 19, 2019; (3) Florida Supreme Court advisory opinion, January 16, 2020, confirming inclusion of LFOs; (4) Eleventh Circuit panel affirmance, February 19, 2020, 950 F.3d 795; (5) class and subclass certification, April 7, 2020; (6) bench trial and permanent injunction, May 24, 2020, 2020 WL 2618062; and (7) Eleventh Circuit en banc reversal, September 11, 2020, 975 F.3d 1016. The district court case was presided over by Judge Robert L. Hinkle; earlier, Chief Judge Mark E. Walker handled initial scheduling before recusal. The consolidated actions included Jones v. DeSantis (lead), Raysor v. Lee (class action), Gruver v. Barton et al., McCoy v. DeSantis, and Mendez v. DeSantis.
results.CW-CA-0005:
Filed on July 18, 2002, this class action challenged the failure to provide medically necessary mental health services to foster children in Los Angeles County and statewide in California. The plaintiffs are foster children (proceeding under pseudonyms) who alleged that children in or at imminent risk of foster care with documented mental health conditions were not receiving required services in home‑like settings. They sued Los Angeles County (and its Department of Children and Family Services) and the Directors of the California Department of Health Services and Department of Social Services. Plaintiffs were represented by public interest and private counsel, including the ACLU of Southern California, Western Center on Law & Poverty, National Center for Youth Law, and the Bazelon Center for Mental Health Law.

The First Amended Complaint (December 20, 2002) asserted federal claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 to enforce Medicaid’s Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment (EPSDT) provisions, and alleged violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act, Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and federal and state due process. Factually, plaintiffs alleged that tens of thousands of foster children with behavioral, emotional, or psychiatric impairments were not being provided medically necessary services (e.g., assessments, intensive home‑based services, case management, “wraparound” services, and therapeutic foster care) and were instead over‑relied upon institutional placements and experienced repeated placement disruptions. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief.

On June 18, 2003, the court certified a statewide class of children in foster care or at imminent risk of placement with documented mental health needs who require individualized mental health services in home or home‑like settings. On July 16, 2003, the court approved a negotiated settlement with Los Angeles County, certified a county subclass, and retained jurisdiction, establishing an advisory panel to monitor county compliance.

As to the State of California, on March 14, 2006, the district court granted a preliminary injunction (433 F. Supp. 2d 1065) requiring the State to provide wraparound services and therapeutic foster care to class members on a consistent statewide basis through Medi‑Cal or other means, and issued a clarifying addendum on May 12, 2006. The Ninth Circuit denied a stay but, on March 23, 2007, reversed and remanded (481 F.3d 1150), holding that EPSDT requires provision of the component services listed in 42 U.S.C. § 1396d(a), and directing the district court to determine whether those components were being effectively provided, rather than requiring specific “bundled” programs; it confirmed a § 1983 private right of action under § 1396a(a)(10).

Following further proceedings and negotiations, the parties reached a statewide settlement. On December 5, 2011, the court entered a Stipulated Judgment pursuant to a Settlement Agreement with the state defendants. The Agreement required (1) development and dissemination of a Medi‑Cal Specialty Mental Health Documentation Manual describing Intensive Care Coordination (ICC), Intensive Home‑Based Services (IHBS), and Therapeutic Foster Care (TFC); (2) submission of State Plan Amendments as needed to ensure Medicaid coverage of these services; (3) adoption of a shared, statewide Core Practice Model using Child and Family Teams; (4) joint management and oversight by the Departments of Health Care Services and Social Services; (5) training, technical assistance, data collection and quality assurance; and (6) a process to identify class members and link them to services. The court retained jurisdiction for 36 months (until December 5, 2014) and appointed a Special Master (Richard Saletta) to assist in developing the Implementation Plan, monitor progress, and report regularly. The United States Department of Justice filed comments supporting final approval, citing consistency with the ADA’s integration mandate and EPSDT requirements.

Throughout 2012–2014, the State filed implementation plans, expanded ICC/IHBS statewide, worked with CMS on TFC coverage, created a shared management structure, and reported on data collection efforts. The Special Master’s November 20, 2014 progress report documented increased delivery of ICC and IHBS to subclass members, the build‑out of county‑level structures, and ongoing work to secure CMS approval for TFC.

Separately, Los Angeles County’s 2003 settlement remained under the court’s jurisdiction and advisory panel oversight, with periodic reports documenting county efforts to implement Child and Family Teams, expand intensive services, reduce use of congregate care, and align practice with the Core Practice Model.

Reported opinions include the district court’s preliminary injunction order (433 F. Supp. 2d 1065 (C.D. Cal. 2006)) and the Ninth Circuit’s decision (Katie A. ex rel. Ludin v. Los Angeles County, 481 F.3d 1150 (9th Cir. 2007)). The case did not proceed to trial; it resolved through the 2003 county settlement and the 2011 statewide settlement, each enforced by the court with monitoring mechanisms.
results.PC-VA-0022:
On December 19, 2014, a Virginia state prisoner filed an individual civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 in the Western District of Virginia against the state corrections department and numerous corrections officials at system and facility level. The prisoner proceeded pro se in the district court; the defendants were represented by the Virginia Office of the Attorney General. The court denied the prisoner’s motion to certify a class and his request for appointment of counsel. Two co‑plaintiffs originally named were severed, leaving a single plaintiff.

The suit challenged Virginia Department of Corrections Operating Procedure 830.A governing “Level S” segregation at Red Onion State Prison and Wallens Ridge State Prison, alleging that the classification and review procedures kept him in highly restrictive solitary conditions without constitutionally adequate process and that those conditions violated the Eighth Amendment. The prisoner, serving a 38‑year sentence for violent offenses and convicted in 2011 of malicious wounding after a 2009 assault on a guard, had been designated a Level S “Intensive Management” (IM) inmate at Red Onion. Under OP 830.A, Level S inmates are divided into Intensive Management and Special Management (SM) paths. SM inmates may progress through a goal‑oriented Step‑Down program toward general population, while IM inmates progress through IM‑0, IM‑1, and IM‑2 “privilege levels,” and, if approved, to an IM Closed Pod (IM‑SL6) intended to improve quality of life for those facing long‑term high security. Level S inmates receive periodic Institutional Classification Authority reviews at least every 90 days. The prisoner contended that IM status effectively barred him from meaningful progress out of segregation, that reviews were arbitrary or perfunctory, and that IM inmates were subjected to harsher conditions than similarly situated SM inmates, violating equal protection. He sought declaratory and injunctive relief (including abolishing OP 830.A and altering conditions) and monetary damages.

The prisoner described conditions that included single‑cell housing, meals in cell, three showers per week, one hour of out‑of‑cell recreation five days per week (alone in a secure area), restraints and escorts whenever out of cell, non‑contact visits, limited phone and commissary privileges, constant lighting, noise, and other restrictions he alleged caused mental and physical harms. The defendants submitted OP 830.A and related classification procedures, and an affidavit explaining the Level S program, IM/SM tracks, privileges, and review mechanisms.

After the court granted leave to amend and denied the defendants’ motion to dismiss, it set a schedule for summary judgment. The magistrate judge had previously granted a protective order staying discovery pending the motion to dismiss. The defendants moved for summary judgment; the plaintiff opposed with a sworn declaration and exhibits.

On September 28, 2016, Judge James P. Jones granted summary judgment to all remaining defendants and dismissed the claim against the Virginia Department of Corrections as legally frivolous. The court held that the plaintiff failed to show a Fourteenth Amendment due process violation, finding that under OP 830.A he received periodic, multi‑level reviews of his status and opportunities to advance in step‑down and privilege levels; and that his restrictive conditions and duration, in light of his offense and institutional record, did not establish deprivation of a protected liberty interest without due process. The court also rejected his Eighth Amendment claim, concluding he had not shown deprivation of a basic human need such as food, shelter, or medical care, deliberate indifference by officials, or injury rising to constitutional magnitude. The court denied the equal protection claim for lack of evidence of purposeful discrimination among similarly situated inmates.

The prisoner appealed. On November 22, 2017, a Fourth Circuit panel (Judges Niemeyer, King, and Floyd) issued an unpublished per curiam decision affirming the district court’s judgment. The appeal was argued with appointed pro bono counsel for the prisoner; the Attorney General’s Office represented the appellees. No trial occurred, and there were no decrees or settlements.

Key docket events:
- March 6, 2015: Class certification and appointment of counsel denied.
- October 29, 2015: Protective order staying discovery granted.
- May 18, 2016: Leave to amend granted; motion to dismiss denied; defendants directed to move for summary judgment.
- September 28, 2016: Summary judgment granted; claims against VDOC dismissed as frivolous.
- November 22, 2017: Fourth Circuit affirmed by unpublished opinion.
results.CJ-MD-0001:
On January 19, 2006, a condemned Maryland inmate filed a federal civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against the Secretary of Public Safety and Correctional Services, the Commissioner of the Division of Correction, two wardens, and unnamed execution team members, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief to bar his execution under Maryland’s current lethal injection practices. The prisoner argued that the three‑drug protocol (sodium thiopental, pancuronium bromide, and potassium chloride), the lack of anesthesiology-qualified personnel, long IV runs across two rooms, and the absence of monitoring for anesthetic depth created a grave and unnecessary risk that he would experience excruciating pain in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments. He cited, among other things, a 1998 execution in which an IV line leaked and the procedure lasted 23 minutes, and he contended his history of intravenous drug use would complicate venous access. The State, represented by the Maryland Attorney General’s Office, opposed emergency relief.

Chief Judge Benson Everett Legg of the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland held expedited hearings on January 24, 27, and February 1, 2006, receiving testimony from medical experts (including an anesthesiologist and a trauma surgeon) and members of the execution team. On February 1, 2006, Judge Legg denied both a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction, finding the inmate had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits under the governing preliminary injunction standard and that Maryland’s protocol, if properly implemented, would render an inmate deeply unconscious before administering the paralytic and potassium chloride. The court noted the State’s protocol called for 3 grams of thiopental and had built‑in redundancy (two IV lines, backup syringes). The prisoner appealed the denial; the Fourth Circuit dismissed/denied the appeal and issued its mandate on February 17, 2006. The district court ordered post‑execution reporting and then proceeded with discovery. A motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust under the Prison Litigation Reform Act was denied on September 15, 2006, after the court found exhaustion was not jurisdictional and that exhaustion had been completed. The court conducted an evidentiary bench proceeding September 19–22, 2006, including testimony from the inmate’s experts and execution team members, and issued rulings on evidentiary motions. In December 2006, the court reopened the record to explore whether qualified medical professionals could be used to assist in executions, but further proceedings were stayed in light of a dispositive state‑court decision described below. Ultimately, with executions in Maryland stayed, the federal case was administratively closed by agreement on August 16, 2012.

Separately, on January 20, 2006, three organizations (NAACP, ACLU of Maryland, and Maryland Citizens Against State Executions) and the same condemned inmate filed an action in the Circuit Court for Baltimore City against the Secretary and the Commissioner alleging that the Division of Correction’s Execution Operations Manual (including the “Lethal Injection Checklist”) conflicted with Maryland’s death penalty statute, Md. Code Ann., Correctional Services § 3‑905, and, in any event, was invalid because it had been adopted without complying with the Maryland Administrative Procedure Act (APA), Md. Code Ann., State Government § 10‑101 et seq. The plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order and preliminary and permanent injunctive relief.

On December 19, 2006, in consolidated appeals that included the Baltimore City APA case and other challenges, the Maryland Court of Appeals (opinion by Judge Alan M. Wilner) held: (1) the Execution Operations Manual’s three‑drug mix and method (including use of two paralytic agents) did not conflict with § 3‑905 and were not unconstitutional on their face; but (2) the detailed “Lethal Injection Checklist,” which specified the contents and manner of administering the drugs, was a “regulation” under the APA because it had general application and future effect and implemented the death penalty statute. Because the Division of Correction had not adopted the checklist pursuant to APA rulemaking (notice, review by the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review, and publication), it was ineffective. The Court of Appeals vacated the denial of injunctive relief and remanded with instructions to enjoin enforcement of the Lethal Injection Checklist until it was properly adopted as a regulation under the APA or exempted by the General Assembly. See Evans v. State, 396 Md. 256 (2006). As a result, Maryland executions were stayed pending APA compliance. In 2010 the Secretary published proposed death penalty regulations in the Maryland Register, but withdrew them in early 2011 for further review. By March 2012, the parties reported that executions remained stayed until regulations were adopted.

Parties and Counsel: In the federal case, the prisoner was represented by private counsel (Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr LLP and associated counsel); the State officials were represented by Assistant Attorneys General from the Maryland Office of the Attorney General. In the state APA action, the organizational plaintiffs (NAACP, ACLU of Maryland, CASE) and the prisoner proceeded against the Secretary of DPSCS and the DOC Commissioner.

Cause of Action and Relief: The federal suit was brought under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 alleging violations of the Eighth Amendment’s Cruel and Unusual Punishments Clause and the Fourteenth Amendment, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief (including a TRO and preliminary injunction) to bar execution under Maryland’s existing lethal injection protocol. The state action sought declaratory and injunctive relief under Maryland law, asserting inconsistency with Md. Code Ann., Corr. Servs. § 3‑905 and failure to comply with the APA.

Judges: Chief Judge Benson Everett Legg presided in the U.S. District Court. Judge Alan M. Wilner authored the Maryland Court of Appeals opinion; Chief Judge Robert M. Bell dissented in part.

Filings and Proceedings: Key filings included the inmate’s January 2006 TRO/PI motion in federal court, the State’s opposition, a two‑day evidentiary hearing (with expert and execution team testimony), and Judge Legg’s February 1, 2006 memorandum denying relief (412 F. Supp. 2d 519). The Fourth Circuit dismissed the appeal and issued a mandate on February 17, 2006. Discovery and motion practice continued through summer 2006; the court denied a motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust on September 15, 2006, held an evidentiary bench proceeding in September 2006, and later reopened the record in December 2006 before staying proceedings. In the state APA action, the Circuit Court initially denied emergency relief, but the Court of Appeals reversed in part, held the checklist to be a regulation, and remanded with instructions to enjoin its enforcement until APA compliance (396 Md. 256 (2006)).

Outcome and Effect: The federal court denied preliminary injunctive relief and did not enter a final merits judgment; the case was administratively closed in August 2012 while Maryland executions remained stayed. In the state action, the Court of Appeals’ injunction against use of the Lethal Injection Checklist remained in effect until the State adopted valid regulations or obtained a legislative exemption. Proposed regulations were published in November 2010 but withdrawn in February 2011; as of March 2012, executions in Maryland were stayed pending adoption of regulations. The state’s lethal injection protocol was thus halted by court order of indefinite duration unless and until the APA was satisfied or the Legislature acted. The Court of Appeals also affirmed the validity of the protocol under § 3‑905 and rejected other consolidated challenges.
results.CW-DC-0001:
Filed June 20, 1989, this class action was brought on behalf of children in the custody of, or known to, the District of Columbia’s child‑welfare system—principally foster children and abused or neglected children reported to authorities—against District officials, including the Mayor and senior human services leadership. The children, represented by private public‑interest counsel (the ACLU Children’s Rights Project/Children’s Rights, later A Better Childhood), sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause; the federal Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 and Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act; and District statutes, including the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect Act of 1977 and the Youth Residential Facilities Licensure Act of 1986. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to end systemic deficiencies—untimely and inadequate investigations of abuse/neglect, failure to provide services to keep families intact, prolonged “emergency care,” inappropriate and unsafe placements, missing case plans and reviews, delayed permanency and adoptions, inadequate staffing, training, and information systems—and to enforce statutory and constitutional requirements.

After a two‑week bench trial, Judge Thomas F. Hogan issued a detailed liability opinion on April 18, 1991 (762 F. Supp. 959), finding “widespread and systematic deficiencies” and holding the District liable under § 1983 for violating federal and local child‑welfare statutes, and, as to children in custody, due process. The court entered a comprehensive consent Remedial Order in August 1991 establishing a court‑appointed Monitor (the Center for the Study of Social Policy) and prescribing detailed requirements for protective services, emergency care, placement standards, case planning, visitation, permanency, staffing and caseload caps, training, licensing, contracting, information systems, and revenue maximization. On appeal, the D.C. Circuit affirmed the judgment on District law grounds and remanded to rest the decree solely on local law (990 F.2d 1319 (D.C. Cir. 1993)); the court adopted a Modified Final Order (MFO) on November 18, 1993 removing federal‑law references while maintaining substantive provisions.

Persistent noncompliance led to enforcement proceedings. In October 1994 the court found contempt and imposed limited receiverships over resource development and protective services. In May 1995, after further failures, the court entered contempt sanctions and established a full receivership over the child‑welfare system (887 F. Supp. 297; General Receivership Order, Aug. 24, 1995). The D.C. Circuit later clarified that any receiver’s authority to override local law must be narrowly tailored to instances necessary to enforce the decree and tied to specific federal law justifications (144 F.3d 847 (D.C. Cir. 1998)). The receivership produced structural changes, including creation of a standalone Child and Family Services Agency (CFSA). By consent order, the court terminated the receivership effective June 15, 2001 and commenced a probationary period with performance standards.

To guide post‑receivership compliance, the court approved an Implementation Plan in 2003 (re‑stating exit benchmarks), amended it in 2007, and, after performance setbacks in 2008 (including highly publicized child fatalities), entered a 2008 Stipulated Order requiring a corrective “strategy plan.” In April 2010 the court held the District in civil contempt for failing to timely produce an adequate annual plan developed in consultation with plaintiffs and to include plaintiffs and the Monitor in selecting a permanent CFSA Director, as required by the stipulation; the court modified the MFO’s planning provisions and adopted a new Implementation and Exit Plan (IEP) with specific exit standards across safety, permanency, well‑being, and systems management. Subsequent Monitor reports documented mixed performance—improvements in health services, licensing, and sibling placement and visits; persistent deficiencies in investigations (especially timely closure and quality), consistent safety assessments during visits, parent‑child visitation, and timely permanency—and the court retained jurisdiction, occasionally ordering corrective actions and imposing sanctions.

Throughout, the court relied on the Monitor (CSSP) to assess compliance, issue bi‑annual reports, and assist the parties. The court repeatedly awarded plaintiffs interim attorneys’ fees and costs for litigation and monitoring (e.g., 1998 and 2000 awards). On August 29, 2019, after mediation, the parties jointly submitted and the court approved an Exit and Sustainability Plan (ESP), replacing the 2010 IEP. The ESP recognizes the District’s sustained compliance by moving 56 exit standards—covering licensing, 24‑hour response, case planning, most visitation and placement standards, training, budgeting, provider payments, and many others—into “Outcomes to be Maintained,” ending routine court reporting on those items. It narrows ongoing external monitoring to a set of “Outcomes to be Achieved,” focusing on remaining problem areas: timely initiation and closure and qualitative adequacy of abuse/neglect investigations; provision of services to promote safety, permanency, and well‑being; safety assessment during worker visits to in‑home and out‑of‑home cases; intensive visitation in the first month after new or changed placements; adherence to the 30‑day limit for emergency/temporary care; and parent–worker and parent–child visitation for reunification cases. The ESP also memorializes CFSA’s self‑regulation and public reporting commitments and “placement array” development to support permanency. Under the ESP, the Monitor will continue bi‑annual reports on the remaining outcomes, and the parties will meet annually to reassess the path to final exit.
